title: forget jane eyre give students
story: Forget Jane Eyre - give students a chance by teaching books they can relate to"Trying to explain to young students who already feel like they have failed, why Jane Eyre is so important to them, is borderline abuse," says lecturer Stephen Tuffin Image: Publicity PictureopinionByStephen Tuffin:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsThis week, in a classroom near you, a baffled teacher will attempt to convince a disillusioned group of GCSE English students that learning why Jane Eyre doesn’t think Mr Rochester loves her, is going to make the world of dference to their futures. Why  No one knows. Or, at least, no one is willing to say. For as far back as anyone can remember, a stream of out-of-touch, often privately educated, Education Secretaries, have signed off on the idea that teaching student’s th century literature, at Level , is just what students need to secure them a decent job in the workplace. Students who don’t pass their GCSEs are forced to repeat what they’ve already failed at. Forced to engage with books written in a language they will never use. Trying to explain to young students who already feel like they have failed, why Jane Eyre is so important to them, is borderline abuse. At a time when young people are turning away from books and literature at an alarming rate, no one in government seems bothered or interested in providing students with something a little more relatable. Last week I had to face one such group. The futility and unfairness of it struck me mid lesson. I had no argument as to why they should engage with Dracula.  Why reading Stoker would be of use, interest, or benefit to them unless they had an express desire to go into further education. Which the vast majority don’t. Starting off a lesson with the words, ‘Today we are going to be looking at Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde’ will mean within two minutes % of a GCSE class will have shut down. Do the powers that be think there is no other literature available to young people  Using contemporary texts by authors like Kit de Waal or Lisa McInerny, would at least give students and teachers a fighting chance. If educators were permitted to teach English using contemporary literature that told of the lives and challenges of iniduals who looked and sounded like the students they were teaching, on subjects like county lines, gangs and drugs, or any other aspect of st century teenage le, more students would engage. It’s what they are familiar with. What takes up much of their time. And using a language they use themselves exploring issues and situations they can identy with. A large section of the materials we currently use to teach our young students are entirely ineffective. In fact, they are worse than ineffective. Relying on these texts throws unnecessary, unhelpful barriers in the paths of students. It damages their already damaged faith in themselves and a system that is supposed to support, nurture, and encourage them. If you don’t believe me, ask them yourselves. @StephenTuffin is a lecturer in Swindon Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative PartyEducationSchoolsPoliticsChristmas partyGCSEsRochester and Strood" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i born here could sent
story: I was born here but could be sent back to where I came from with no warningThe governments Nationality and Borders Bill could strip people of their British citizenship without notice or warning - even , like me, you were born in the UK, writes Unzela KhanAccording to this government, as long as I am a good immigrant, I can stay in the UK... even though Im just as British as you Image: Unzela KhanopinionByUnzela Khan:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsIn October  I was born in a London hospital - my parents and four-month-old brother had come from Pakistan the previous year, with my father attaining a work visa. In the following year, all three received an indefinite leave to remain, and a year after this, they received their British Citizenship. With this, I also automatically gained citizenship through my parents - and of course, I was born here - so for all intents and purposes, I was and am British. Growing up in North London, I went to school in Barnet and then went on to secondary school nearby as well. Ultimately, I graduated from University of London while working multiple jobs throughout my university years. I then started my career as a journalist and hoped to make a change because the industry lacked British south Asians, and coverage around the community has been predominantly negative. There are around six million people like me, with similar stories of being born and brought up here, working in the UK and classing themselves as British Pakistani - which, despite having Pakistani at the end of it, does not make the aposBritishapos part of it any less credible - surely  Although at times it feels as though we are unwanted, this country is where we entered the world and is what we know. Evenwe decide to visit our home countries to gain more of a connection with our cultures, at the end of the day we are British citizens, right  But as much as we try to cling on to being British Pakistani or British Bangladeshi, British anything, the second part of the title has become a tool to ensure we know that we are in fact second-class citizens. This is because even though I was born here, I can be deprived of my citizenshipI am able to become a national of another country - for me, I could be deported to Pakistan on the governmentaposs whim. Despite being born and brought up here, clause , proposed by Priti Patel in July and updated last month, would allow for the Home Office to deprive me of my citizenship without delivering physical notication.This means,I went abroad and the government was unable to contact me, before boarding a plane back I could be told my passport is no longer valid without any warning.Mohammed Tasnime Akunjee, the lawyer known for representing Shamima Begum, explained how the new clause impacts Brits like me. He said: The existing law is thatthe Home Secretary deems you not conducive to the public good, and wish to strip you of citizenship, they have to sent you a notice of their decision with a reason for why they are stripping you of citizenship. However, now with the new clause, they donapost have to tell you, youaposll only be told when you try board a plane and your passport is no longer al. The government has said those who are deprived of their citizenship without notice have the right to appeal, but Mr Akunjee says there are issues with this.  He said: You need a physical notice in order to appeal a decision -you donapost have that then the courts will demand that you prove that you have actually have been stripped. You have to acquire that proof and be able to submit that to the court before you can even appeal. Additionally, although some might think that being born here would put you less at risk of being deprived of your status, Mr Akunjee says from a legal perspective, it does not. He said: Both peoplecan be stripped of their citizenship, being born or not born here doesnapost make a dference in respect of this bill. According to , the Home Office has said: “British citizenship is a privilege, not a right. Deprivation of citizenship on conducive grounds is rightly reserved for those who pose a threat to the UK or whose conduct involves very high harm. The Nationality and Borders Bill will amend the law so citizenship can be deprived where it is not practicable to give notice, for example,there is no way of communicating with the person.” So this means that as long as I am a good immigrant, I can stay in the UK  ButI was white, as I would be less likely to be able to get another nationality I would be more likely to keep my British citizenship regardless of what threat I pose to the public. *A version of this piece originally appeared on MyLondon Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Priti PatelHome OfficePoliticsShamima Begum" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: invitations downing street flat party
story: Invitations to Downing Street flat party went out across Whitehall, claims CummingsDominic Cummings - who quit as a top adviser the same day - said the event had been an "organised party" for which their had been formal invitations. London was under Tier  restrictions at the time Image: PAByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Invitations to a party in Boris Johnsonaposs flat while London was under Covid restrictions went out aposacross Whitehallapos, Dominic Cummings has claimed.The Prime Minister on Wednesday denied a party had taken place in his residence above  Downing Street on November , while London was in Tier  restrictions. But Mr Cummings, who quit his job as one of Mr Johnsonaposs most senior advisers the same day, today accused the PM of lying about the soiree. He said the event had been an organised party, for which there had been formal invitations.Mr Cummings was asked about the party during a QA on his £-a-month Substack website. Asked about PMaposs claim there was no party in the flat on November , Mr Cummings wrote: Obv he was lying. He went on: There were invites sent across Whitehall, it was an organised party. [Johnson] know[s] this and tried to lie his way out, but was f****d by the video.  The video in question was a leaked clip of former Johnson spokesperson Allegra Stratton joking about a later party in Number , on December . Earlier, Mr Cummings tweeted: Thereaposs lots of pictures of the parties which will inevitably get out. And invite lists beyond No to other departments. And he had referred to reporting published at the time that there had been a victory party in Downing Street following Mr Cummingsapos leaving No. On November  , the Mail on Sunday reported claims there had been boisterous gathering in the flat, as allies of Carrie Johnson celebrated his departure. Allies of Mrs Johnson - then Ms Symonds - denied the reports at the time. And asked whether the party took place at PMQs on Wednesday, Mr Johnson said: No.Yesterday, it was confirmed that as well as investigating the party held in Number  on December , a second gathering on Novmeber  would also be subject to a probe by Cabinet Secretary Simon Case. Tory Minister Michael Ellis told MPs that the investigation will establish the facts around events alleged to have taken place in Downing Street on November  and December . It will also look at a gathering at the Department for Education on December . All three events - which sources said took place despite Covid restrictions - were first revealed by the Mirror.The Prime Minister finally apologised on Wednesday after a clip emerged of his own staff joking about a “not socially distanced” bash on December  last year.  He announced a probe into the event by Cabinet Secretary Simon Case - but his spokesman confirmed that inquiry will only cover the events of December  last year. But Mr Ellis said on Thursday that it would cover allegations of a second No event on November  - during a national lockdown - where sources claimed Mr Johnson addressed a leaving do. Last night new polling gave Labour a six point lead over the Tories, as revelations over rule-breaking Christmas parties and sleaze hit Mr Johnson in the polls.An exclusive survey, conducted by Survation on December , after the Mirroraposs bombshell story about No aposs lockdown-breaking festive knees-up, sees support for Labour soar to %while the Conservatives slump to %. It represents a breakthrough for Keir Starmer as it is the highest poll lead for his party since Boris Johnson took power.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Plan BBoris JohnsonCabinetJohnsonsConservative PartyMail on SundayPoliticsChristmas party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: labour opens up astonishing six
story: Exclusive: New poll gives Labour astonishing six-point lead over the Tories after No partySurvation poll in wake of Downing Street Christmas party revelations sees backing for Keir Starmer soar to % - the highest since Boris Johnson became Prime MinisterLabour leader Sir Keir Starmer Image: PAByRachel WearmouthSenior Political CorrespondentAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsLabour has opened up a six-point lead over the Tories as revelations over rule-breaking Christmas parties and sleaze hit Boris Johnson in the polls.An exclusive survey, conducted by Survation on December , after the Mirroraposs bombshell story about No aposs lockdown-breaking festive knees-up, sees support for Labour soar to %while the Conservatives slump to %. It represents a breakthrough for Keir Starmer as it is the highest poll lead for his party since Boris Johnson took power. The last time backing for Labour reached %, with the same pollster, was January , , when Theresa May was PM and Jeremy Corbyn was at the Oppositionaposs helm.Ed Daveyaposs Lib Dems polled at % , while right-wing populist party Reform UK, headed by Brexiteer Richard Tice, represents a new threat to the Tories, taking % . Backing for the Greens was also up at % . Additionally, % of Brits surveyed believe the Government has worse standards than it had in previous years.And % said the Tories do believe there is aposone rule for them and one rule for everyone apos.It comes as the Prime Minister attempts to fend off a barrage of criticism over the secret festive bash on December  last year. The Met Police has ruled out an official investigation into alleged breaches of Covid rules, but the PM has asked Cabinet Secretary Simon Case to establish the facts. Leaked footage of staff, including the PMaposs former spokeswoman Allegra Stratton, joking about cheese and wine at the bash and definitely no social distancing, however, sparked fresh public anger about the get-together. Ms Stratton resigned on Wednesday after the video emerged. Meanwhile, the Conservatives are battling to hang on to power in a crunch by-election in North Shropshire after Owen Paterson quit over repeated and egregious breaches of lobbying rules. The scandal led to numerous allegations of Tory sleaze, with a string of MPs found to have lucrative second jobs as political consultants. Mr Johnson was also forced to U-turn on his bid to rip up standards rules. The Government could also be facing a backbench Tory rebellion over the PMaposs new plan B restrictions in Parliament next week. title: nicola sturgeon urges people cancel
story: Nicola Sturgeon urges people to cancel Xmas parties amid fears of a tsunami of Omicron casesThe First Minister told Scots the new strain was a "very severe challenge" while Downing Street said "we do not think there is a need to cancel people coming together in hospitality venues"Nicola Sturgeon Image: Daily RecordByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Dec | commentsNicola Sturgeon has urged people to cancel Christmas parties and work from home as she warned Britain faced a tsunami of Omicron infections.The First Minister, who will attend a Cobra meeting on the pandemic with Boris Johnson and other leaders later today, told Scots the new strain “threatens a rapid and large surge of Covid- cases”.It came as Downing Street doubled down on its position on Christmas parties in England, saying we do not think there is a need to cancel people coming together in hospitality venues. The FM said the Scottish Government was acting as Omicron was set to overtake Delta as the most dominant strain within days, adding Covid could put signicant additional pressure on hospitals and other health and care services at the peak pressure of winter. “The fact is, we do face a renewed and very severe challenge in the face of of the new Omicron iant,” she said at a briefing in Edinburgh. “To be blunt, because of the much greater and faster transmissibility of this new iant, we may be facing – indeed we may be starting to experience – a potential tsunami of infections.” Meanwhile in Wales, First Minister Mark Drakeford also sounded the alarm over the new Covid strain, telling reporters at a briefing that restrictions would be reviewed weekly. The Department for Health said on Thursday there had been , new Covid infections and fears for the NHS are growing.The Prime Minister announced on Wednesday that England would move to Plan B restrictions, with people told to work from home as of Monday. The ramping up of Covid curbs also means more mandated mask-wearing and next week MPs will vote on a Covid pass scheme for some venues. But the Prime Ministeraposs authority has been damaged over the lockdown-breaking Christmas bash in No last December - first revealed by the Mirror. On Thursday night it emerged his communications director Jack Doyle gave a thank-you speech at the event and handed staff spoof awards.Tory backbenchers are also threatening a major rebellion over the Covid pass plan while Labour has said the PM is not fit to lead the country as the pandemic rages.Askedpeople in England should cancel their Christmas parties too, Mr Johnsonaposs spokesman said on Friday: Under Plan B, weaposre not shutting hospitality. The use of certication enables a number of venues to remain open when otherwise we would have had to close them for public health reasons as we have had to do previously. We understand fully the impact that these measures have had on hospitality in the past and certication allows them to remain trading. We do not think there is a need to cancel people coming together in hospitality venues. news politics shock-poll-finds--brits-"Boris Johnson declines to repeat official denial about staff party at No ByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsBoris Johnson’s efforts to tackle the new Coronavirus iant are at risk as a Mirror survey has found three in four Brits are less likely to follow fresh Covid restrictions following revelations of lockdown parties in Downing Street. The UK recorded its highest number of Covid infections since January  today and UK scientists warned millions could catch the new strain before the New Year as it will become the dominant iant in the UK by mid-December. The Survation poll for the Mirror reveals % of people are less likely to follow Covid rulesGovernment officials have broken them. The survey of , Brits online found % believe Government officials did break the rules at the peak of the second wave, with % stating the incidents should be investigated by the police. And % of Conservative voters who backed Boris Johnson in the last General Election believe the Tories think itaposs one rule for them and another for everyone .The poll comes after Professor Chris Whitty said he fears Brits will not accept new lockdown restrictions after enduring almost two years of the pandemic. Speaking to a  at the Local Government Association he added: “My greatest worry at the moment is that people…we need to do something more muscular at some point, whether it’s for the current new iant or at some later stage, can we still take people with us ”  The Office for National Statisticsinfection survey found  in  people had Covid in England, in the week ending December . This equates to around , people. On Friday face masks were made mandatory in most indoor spaces including cinemas, theatres, churches and galleries.And from Monday those who can work from home are advised to do so, and on Wednesday the NHS Covid Passwill become mandatory for entry into nightclubs and other large gatherings.The PM’s spokesman slapped down rumours of a Covid ‘Plan C’ or a ‘Plan B plus’ being prepared for the New Year just in case the plan B measures did not curb the new iant. Plan B measures are set to be introduced next week, with MPs set to vote on the measures in the Commons on Tuesday. But at least  Tory MPs are set to rebel and vote against the introduction of tighter Covid restrictions, with many furious with Mr Johnson’s handling of Downing Street party revelations.  Former Tory chief whip Mark Harper said the PMaposs authority has been diminished by the Owen Paterson sleaze row and the alleged Downing Street party. He told the Commons on Wednesday: “Why should people listen to the Prime Minister’s instructions to follow the rules when people inside Number  Downing Street don’t do so ”And renowned rebel Steve Baker told the Mirror he hoped Labour would vote against the measures.But shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting slammed rumours of Labour voting against plan B restrictions in order to defeat the PM.He told BBC ’s Radio  Today programme “public health has always come first for the Labour Party during the pandemic. Despite the trouble the Government finds themselves in, public health will still come before party politics”. Sir Keir Starmer said the booster programme should have been ramped up weeks ago. “The Government pooh-poohed that it’s now doing it but again, as ever, too late, he added.The Survation study put Labour on a six-point lead over the Conservatives, which suggests voters have lost faith in Mr Johnsonaposs handling of the pandemic following the party scandal. Since the Mirror first revealed parties were held at the Prime Ministeraposs Number  flat in the run up to Christmas last year, the PM is now facing accusations of seven separate parties and drinks doaposs held across Westminster in November and December last year. Cabinet Secretary Simon Case is currently investigating three dates on which bashes were said to have been held in breach of lockdown rules. They are, a No leaving do on November  at which the PM spoke a No Christmas party on December  and a Department for Education bash on December . Downing Street has cancelled its Christmas party this year blaming the increase in workload for the cancelled plans. The Prime Ministeraposs spokesman said: I think weaposve made it clear since the latest situation with Omicron, obviously thataposs taking up a great deal of time at the moment. He added: Thereaposs no plans for [a party] in Number .On November , sources told the Mirror people gathered for drinks in Boris and Carrie Johnsonaposs flat above  Downing Street. And on the same day, farewell drinks were held in number s round table room - the night Dominic Cummings quit. Two weeks later on November , sources claim  to  people crammed into a room at Number  to say goodbye to top aide Cleo Watson, an ally of Cummings. Former Education Secretary Gavin Williamson has admitted to holding a canapes reception for his top team on December . Four days later people working on the London mayoral campaign for candidate Shaun Bailey held their own ‘raucous’ party. And on December  the Mirror broke the story about the Number  Christmas Party. ITV News reported on Thursday that Jack Doyle, who was then deputy director of communications at No , addressed up to  people at a Christmas gathering said to have been held on December .He offered to resign but the PM turned it down. A Number  spokesperson said Ed Oldfield is still in his position and the PM is still confident with his position, despite accepting Allegra Stratton’s resignation. title: tough covid curbs needed next
story: Tough Covid curbs needed by next week to save NHS from , patients a dayThe NHS could be overrun by , people a day being admitted with Covid unless new curbs are brought in by next week to stop the spread of the Omicron iant, it is reportedNHS staff wear PPE as they treat a coronavirus patient Image: Adam Gerrard Sunday MirrorByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments The UK government has been told that tougher Covid restrictions are needed as soon as next week to prevent hospitalisations from passing last winteraposs peak it is reported.Public health officials are advising that eventhe rapidly spreading Omicron iant causes less serious illness than Delta, it could lead to , people being admitted to NHS hospitals per day.Health Secretary Sajid Javid was given a presentation from the UK Health Security Agencythis week where he was told that “stringent action” would be needed on or before December the iant’s doubling time stays at . days,reported.Prof Neil Ferguson, from Imperial College London, whose data was key to the UK going into lockdown in March , told the newspaper that projections suggest Omicron could “very substantially overwhelm the NHS, getting up to peak levels of admissions of , people per day”. He predicted that the figure could be reached “sometime in January”the iant is resistant to existing protection and it has a similar severity to Delta - which is not yet known.  “Even the best-case scenarios involve several-fold more admissions per day than we’re getting at the moment – we are at about  right now,” he added. It comes as scientists say that Omicron could become the dominant iant by as soon as next week. And the government is currently looking at putting in stricter restrictions, it is reported. Daily Covid- cases have now reached their highest level in almost a year and the UKHSA predicted that,current trends continue, the UK will exceed one million infections by the end of the month. The UKHSA has also found that the AstraZeneca and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines provided “much lower” levels of protection against symptomatic infection with Omicron compared to Delta.Cabinet minister Michael Gove warned of a “deeply concerning situation” after holding a Cobra meeting on Friday afternoon to discuss the latest data and the co-ordinated response across the four nations.The government said there had been a further , lab-confirmed Covid- cases in the UK and the last time a higher daily figure was reported was on January , when , cases were recorded. An additional  confirmed cases of the Omicron iant have been reported across the UK, bringing the total number to ,. Dr Mary Ramsay, head of immunisation at the UKHSA, said early data indicates that “a few months after the second jab, there is a greater risk of catching the Omicron iant compared to Delta strain”. She added: “The data suggest this risk is signicantly reduced following a booster vaccine, so I urge everyone to take up their booster when eligible.” Gove said the Omicron iant is doubling every two to three days in England “and possibly even faster in Scotland”. He added that % of reported cases in London are the new iant, and warned that evidence suggests Omicron is “more likely” than past Covid iants to “potentially” lead to hospital admissions among the fully vaccinated.  Scotland’s First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has warned of the possibility of a “tsunami of infections” from the new iant – and said she could not rule out more restrictions north of the border as a result.But so far Boris Johnson has “no plans” to go further with measures in England, amid claims that he is considering a Plan C with tougher restrictions.Now under Plan B, people are required to wear masks in more indoor spaces including museums, galleries and community centres. There will be ato working from home guidance from Monday, and mandatory Covid passports for large venues from Wednesday.The new regulations will be put to a debate and vote in the Commons next week – and with Labour ’s support they are certain to be approved despite the prospect of a large Conservative revolt.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSOmicron iantCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: treasury staff held lockdown drinks
story: Treasury staff held lockdown drinks party to celebrate Rishi Sunaks spending review"It wasn’t a formal party but perhaps in hindsight it wasn’t the most sensible thing to do,” a source saidMr Sunak is not thought to have been at the party to celebrate his Spending Review Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsTreasury staff held a lockdown drinks party to celebrate Rishi Sunakaposs spending review, it has been revealed. Some staff who worked on the  autumn spending review had office drinks while England was under lockdown restrictions.It comes as Boris Johnson battles mounting revelations of rule-breaking festivities in Downing Street in the run-up to last Christmas.The Times reported that around two dozen civil servants were present for the drinks on November , . A Treasury spokesman said: A number of HMT staff came into the office to work on the Spending Review . We have been made aware that a small number of staff had impromptu drinks around their desks after the event. The Treasury did not organise an in-person departmental party last Christmas.  “They’d all been working really hard,” a source told the Times. “They had to be in the office anyway that day. It wasn’t a formal party but perhaps in hindsight it wasn’t the most sensible thing to do.” At the time non-essential shops, leisure and entertainment venues were closed as well as pubs, bars and restaurants, and people were urged to stay at home except for limited reasons including workit could not be done from home.The Times said Chancellor Rishi Sunak was not at the event and that it is understood he was not aware of it at the time.Downing Street said it has cancelled any plans to hold a Christmas party this year. It came as Boris Johnsonaposs ex-aide Dominic Cummings said there are lots of photos of parties in No  that will inevitably get out.Mr Cummings dismissed defences from the Prime Ministeraposs allies that he would not have known about celebrations going on under his roof amid signs Mr Johnsonaposs popularity is slumping.  Government chief whip Mark Spencer insisted Downing Street staff were not drinking alcohol and partying during Covid restrictions after it emerged the Prime Ministeraposs press chief addressed staff at one event last Christmas.No  said Mr Johnson retained full confidence in Jack Doyle to serve as communications director despite ITV reporting he addressed up to  people and made a speech at one party on December .Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON JohnsonsThe TreasuryThe TimesPlan BJack DoyleMark SpencerBoris JohnsonCivil servantsPoliticsChristmas party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news politics what-covid-plan-c-what-"Boris Johnson announces move to Plan B for Covid restrictionsByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Tougher restrictions are being brought to tackle the spread of the Omicron iant as Boris Johnson implemented his Covid Plan B.The Prime Minister said on Wednesday that people in England should work from home where possible from December , while masks will be mandated in most public indoor venues from Friday. Vaccines passports will also be required for nightclubs and large events from December .But some experts have questioned whether the toolkit of measures will be enough to curb the new strain, with reports of officials drawing up Plan C with even tougher rules. Downing Street said on Friday there was growing confidence that the new iant spreads more quickly than Delta and there was some evidence of vaccine escape.Scotlandaposs First Minister Nicola Sturgeon warned of a possible tsunami of infections ahead of a four-nations Cobra emergency meeting chaired by Cabinet Minister Michael Gove on Friday afternoon. Here we sort the fact from the fiction on future Covid restrictions in England. What is Plan C  Officially, there is no Plan C. The Governmentaposs Covid Winter Plan, published in September, includes a section on Plan B which has a string of measures to imposethe Covid situation worsens. Boris Johnson pulled the trigger on Plan B on Wednesday, with masks becoming mandatory for most indoor public spaces from Friday, and vaccine passports made a legal requirement for nightclubs and large events like football matches from Wednesday. Brits will be ordered to work from home againthey can from Monday. This was thought to be enough to keep the virus at bay over the winter, along with the mass booster programme. But the arrival of Omicron has changed things. Downing Street say there is no official Plan C amid reports officials are drawing up a contingency blueprint with more restrictions.  The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said on Friday there were no plans to go beyond what weaposve set out already when askedthere was going to be a published Plan C. But he added: Obviously we need to keep the characteristics of this iant under review, and we would actnecessary, but thereaposs no plans to go beyond what we set out. Askedthere was a Plan C document, he said: Not that Iaposm aware of. As a responsible Government, of course, you would expect us to... we have an array, already, of options available to us in terms of what measures we can take to mitigate a growth of any iant or virus. But there are no plans to go beyond that currently. What restrictions could be included in Plan C  There are plenty of restrictions that could come in to get infection rates down. Working from home is one of the big levers the Government can pull - and this is already coming into force next week. The other big one is a reduction on household mixing, which was mooted as a contingency plan back in October. However this would be highly unpopular and it doesnapost seem to be on the cards so far. Here are some of the ideas that could be in the pipeline. Hospitality check-ins Punters could be asked to use the NHS Covid app to check into pubs and restaurants, to help contact tracers track the spread of the disease. This rule was in place earlier this year as hospitality venues reopened after lockdown but it was later abandoned. Use of the app fell after the so-called pingdemic when hundreds of thousands of people were told to isolate, leading to staff shortages across a number of industries. In August the rules were changed so double vaccinated people no longer had to isolatepinged by the app. Instead they were advised to take a PCR testthey came into contact with an infected person.  Face masks in all indoor spaces Rules on face coverings have been tightened since Friday, to cover indoor spaces such as theatres and cinemas as well as shops and public transport. But officials are said to be considering making it mandatory in all indoor spaces, which would include hospitality too. Vaccine passports in more venues From December , people will have to prove they are double jabbed or have had a negative Covid test to go to nightclubs and large events like football matches. But this could be broadened to smaller venues too. The Government has been reluctant to require vaccine passports for pubs and other hospitality venues but this could be considered.  Tougher isolation rules Self isolation rules were loosened in the summer so double vaccinated people didnapost have to stay at home for  daysthey came into contact with an infected person. Following the emergence of Omicron, the rules were tweaked so anyone who is a contact of an Omicron case has to isolate regardless of vaccination status. Bringing back the -day rule could have an impact - but it would be controversial again. What would cause Plan C to be triggered  The Government usually refuses to say explicitly what thresholds need to be met to lead to new restrictions - as the situation can change rapidly. But we can take some educated guesses based on the Winter Plan and previous lockdown rules.Throughout the pandemic, one of the key aims of restrictions is to prevent the NHS coming under unsustainable pressure. Hospitalisation rates are a key thing to watch for as large numbers of people being admitted onto Covid wards would put the health service under strain. How well vaccines are working is another critical factor, as the protection offered by the jab has allowed everyone toto some semblance of ordinary le. One of the big unknowns about the Omicron iant is how well the existing vaccines work against it. This is what scientists are currently trying to find out. The transmissibility of the new iant is also important - and how sick people are becoming from it. The new iant may seem frightening but it is worth remembering that we didnapost have the vaccine last winter, which is the best protection against the virus. When could that happen  The short answer is we donapost know. Experts are still working to understand the new iant and the scientic advice will be critical to whatever decisions the Government makes. There are some indications that the new iant may cause less serious illness than feared - but this could still have a big impact on the NHSit spread quickly and infects lots of people. There is also the political angle, as lots of Tory MPs are unhappy with the idea of further restrictions - so there could be some big parliamentary battlesthe Prime Minister tries to bring in fresh curbs. MPs will vote on Tuesday on the Plan B measures, which would be reviewed again in the New Year. However the Government can bring in additional restrictions soonerthe public health case is strong enough. news uk-news banksy-launches-shirt-range-raise-"Banksy fans queue for limited edition T-shirts in BristolByChiara FiorilloNews ReporterRod MinchinBen Bloch:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec Artist Banksy has designed and launched a T-shirt range to raise funds for four people accused of criminal damage over the toppling of a statue in Bristol. The defendants will go on trial on Monday after being accused of pulling down the statue of th century slave trader Edward Colston during a Black Lives Matter protest on June  last year.The anonymous artist announced on Instagram he created a limited edition grey souvenir T-shirt to mark the occasion.The T-shirts, which went on sale in Bristol today, have a picture of Colstonaposs empty plinth with a rope hanging off, with debris and a discarded sign nearby and BRISTOL written above. Banksy said in the social media post that proceeds from the sale will be given to the four people facing trial next week in the city accused of criminal damage, so they can go for a pint. The Bristol-based artist said sales would be limited to one per person and each T-shirt would cost £ plus VAT. Banksy wrote in the caption: Next week the four people charged with pulling down Colston’s statue in Bristol are going on trial. Iaposve made some souvenir shirts to mark the occasion. Available today th December from ious outlets in the city .  Rhian Graham, , Milo Ponsford, , Jake Skuse, , and Sage Willoughby, , face trial at Bristol Crown Court from Monday. The bronze memorial to the slave merchant was pulled down during a protest in June last year, before being dumped in Bristol Harbour and later recovered by Bristol City Council. Charges allege that the four defendants, without lawful excuse, jointly and with others, damaged the statue, a listed monument belonging to the city council.  The defendants are accused of committing the offence intending to destroy or damage such property or being reckless as to whether such property would be destroyed or damaged. Further details on the sale of T-shirts created by Banksy were announced this morning at am on the Ujima Radio breakfast show, a local station. They will be sold in the following locations:Frontline Video in St Paulaposs Hakuna Matata on Stapleton Road in Easton That Thing on Stokes Croft Friendly Records in Bedminster Rough Trade RecordsBristol Live reports that people have been queuing this morning to get hold of the T-shirts.A seller on Ebay already posted the T-shirt on the website with a price of £,.  Today, there will also be a protest organised by campaigners in support of the four defendants. They are also planning to hold a peaceful rally outside Bristol Crown Court on the first day of the trial of the four people accused of criminal damage. The trial is expected to last up to eight days.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON BanksyCriminal damageCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: can drink alcohol before after
story: Can I drink alcohol before or after my Covid vaccine - and what are the side effectsThe government is continuing to encourage people to receive their vaccines. With Christmas parties in full swing, people may want to knowthey can drink before they are given the jabCoronavirus vaccines can cause minor side effects and drinking booze may not help Image: Barcroft Media via Getty ImagesByBenjamin LynchSEO writer:,  Dec | commentsVaccines are vitally important for tackling the coronavirus pandemic. The government hopes that despite new restrictions such as Plan B, as well as further restrictions possible in the form of aposPlan C apos, hospital admissions will be lower due to vaccinations.When the UK was forced to lockdown in  and early , most of the population was unvaccinated against the virus. Receiving the vaccine should not be too much of an inconvenience unless you are someone who may have a reaction to it. Some people have experienced brief, flu-like symptoms after receiving it, but most are expected to be fighting fit and are welcome to socialise after being vaccinated. So can you drink alcohol before and after your vaccine  Can I drink alcohol before or after having the Covid- vaccine   It is probably best to avoid drinking before and after the vaccine and you are only damaging yourselfyou have been drinking excessively. Alcohol may harm your immune response triggered by the vaccine by suppressing your immune system. If your immune system is slower to react, then the effectiveness of the vaccine could be impacted.  As for drinking after receiving the vaccine, people have been known to have side effects caused by the jab. Alcohol will not help any of these symptoms and is not a cure for feeling ill, it is just likely to dehydrate you and you will feel worse. Can alcohol affect the immune system   When a person is exposed to a virus, the bodyaposs antibodies are tasked with fighting off this illness. Healthier people with better and faster immune systems can fight viruses off more quickly. This is why older people are more at risk from viruses like Covid-, as their immune response is typically slower. Yale Medicine addiction medicine specialist Dr. E. Jenner Edelman, told Healthline: Alcohol has erse adverse effects throughout the body, including on all cells of the immune system, that lead to increased risk of serious infections.With COVID-, alcohol is likely to interfere with an inidual’s ability to clear SARS-CoV- and cause people to suffer worse outcomes. What are the side effects of the coronavirus vaccine   In February, around one in three people reported some kind of side effect from the vaccine, including some soreness around the area the needle penetrated the skin. Side effects are caused by the bodyaposs response to the vaccine and not the virus itself.Dr Anna Goodman of Guyaposs and St Thomasapos Hospital, in London, told the BBC that a heavier response to the vaccine does not mean you are more immune to the virus than others. She said: Because you have more fever, that doesnapost mean you are more immune. You canapost presume it to. People have been known to experience the following side effects caused by receiving the vaccine: Headaches Fever Muscle pain Feeling tired Nausea Chills Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Plan BImmune systemAlcoholCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: charlotte looks like mini queen
story: Charlotte looks like a mini Queen in family Christmas snap, royal fans sayPrince William and Kate Middleton have released a Christmas family photo and royal fans were quick to see how similar Charlotte looks to her great gran the QueenThe family photo on the Cambridges Christmas card Image: KENSINGTON PALACE AFP via GettyByEscher WalcottOK! reporterTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsA Christmas family snap of the Cambridges and their kids has led to royal fans quickly picking up on the likeness that Princess Charlotte has for her great gran the Queen. William and Kate released the photo on Friday afternoon with their three children and Charlotte quickly went viral as people saw the similarity to the Queen, even in the way she posed.The six-year-old was sat beside her father Prince William while her two brothers, Prince George, eight, and Prince Louis, three, were sitting nearer to their mum, reported OK! Unlike in previous years for Christmas photos the family were not dressed formally but had summer outfits on. “Delighted to share a new image of the family, which features on this year’s Christmas card,” wrote the Cambridges.  Princess Charlotte wore a blue gingham-patterned dress for the shoot and looked serene in front of the camera with her hands crossed in front of her and her long hair swept to the side. Fans quickly picked up on Charlotte looking a lot like her great grandmother, the Queen, and even had Her Majestyaposs typical pose.“What a handsome family. You can really see Queen Elizabeth in Princess Charlotte,” one person wrote on Twitter.“Charlotte is such cute princess, she is a the mini version of the Queen,” a second follower commented, while another added: “Charlotte is the image of the Queen. Adorable.”  The Mountbatten-Windsor family photo comes days after Kate hosted the charity carol event, Together at Christmas, held at Westminster Abbey in honour of those who have given their support to communities in need during the pandemic. It was a rare occasion where Kate was seen at a public event with the rest of her family including her parents and brother and sister. The Cambridgesapos kids were not at the event and a royal expert said they do not like to put them on ceremony at public occasions. The reality is that William and Kate have a rule that they do not take the children on any official engagements, said Duncan Larcombe about their absence at the carol event earlier this week. “It was on a school night and they are pretty strict. The children are in a rather strict regime so that might have been the reason, but the fact it was a televised official engagement shows that William and Kate are still reluctant to focus too greatly officially on their family and their children. title: couple quoted 16k transform ugly
story: Couple quoted £k to transform ugly garden do it themselves and save £kElizabeth Astin, , and her husband bought furniture and decorations from discount stores Amazon, BM and The Range then carried out the physical work themselves to cut costsThe couple say they saved £, Image: LatestDealsByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Dec | commentsA couple quoted £, to transform their “barren and ugly’ garden saved a whopping £, by doing most of the project themselves. Elizabeth Astin, , and her husband, sourced materials, furniture and bargain decorations from the likes of Amazon, BM and The Range instead of paying professionals to do the legwork. The couple, from Birmingham, sourced wooden sleepers for their builder saving them £,.Their nephew fitted the electrics and they built a relaxing zen area using leftover supplies, , BirminghamLive reports. Elizabeth sourced bargain decorations and furniture from Amazon, BM and The Range.  She told money-saving community LatestDeals: We moved into our house as a new building  years ago. When we bought it, the agent told us that there was no back garden. What they meant was that there was a lower patio area with a huge retaining wall and a sloping upper area that was north facing. Not very attractive at all. Still, it stood us in good stead over the years. Our girls had water fights, we bought numerous bouncy castles, water slides and paddling pools and my husband and his dad made a decking for the adults to chill. We always wanted to improve it but it was for the kids. While they were young, it was more important for them to have a safe place to play. Now they are grown up, we wanted to finally tackle the garden and improve it. The first step was planning. It was dficult with the garden being on a slope. We realised we needed at least two levels or terraced areas to be able to have somewhere to entertain and relax. The back garden gets sun at the top of the garden all day long, she said, so the couple worked around it to make sure they maximised the sunshine.She added: Before starting on the makeover, I had spent a lot of time browsing the Facebook group ‘DIY on a budget gardens’.I learned a great deal and got lots of inspiration from group members. We were always mindful to try and keep costs down without compromising on quality and our dreams.  We saved up for all of this including replacing the iron railings with a lovely glass fence. It was a big project. The existing decking was built by my husband and father in law when we moved in two decades ago. This had to be pulled down and the areas levelled. We had a beautul clematis that sadly had to be pulled down too and that was done by my husband - it took him two days to do it. It was a complete makeover. We also had to pull down and replace an ugly iron fence on top of the large retaining wall. The couple paid a builder to do the landscaping, build the patios and replace concrete slabs with Indian stone, which took up the main budget. Elizabeth said: We had to get someone in to build the glass and steel fence as well as do parts of the project ourselves due to the nature of the makeover and the retaining wall. We had to ensure the wall could hold the new patio areas so we needed professional help. The building work was £k but we saved money by having the electrics fitted by our nephew who is an electrician. Also, we managed to reduce the price by using wooden railway sleepers rather than building retaining walls. The builder provided all the materials. We had an original quote for £k from another builder so by having the sleepers we saved approximately £k. The glass fence was £, and once that was installed, my husband used the leftover Indian stone and sleepers from the builder to create a little zen area. He built a bench and a space to put a relaxing water feature on. We also reused the old gray slabs from the original patio and laid them in the front garden, to build a little seating area. Part of this area included tub chairs we already had from Aldi, which we had bought the year before for £. I bought furnishings such as cushions and decorations from Amazon and BM. I probably spent around £ on these, again trying to source the best value for money.  The day bed was from The Range. I searched for the best price and got it for around £. The same bed on other websites were between £ and £ so I basically got it half price. I also wanted to arrange the plants to suit the new makeover. Most of them were already there before - I just replanted them. We did, however, buy a few more from a local garden center. They were very cheap - probably no more than £ for all of them. Now the project is finally done, it’s our safe haven. We managed to save thousands by combining professional work with DIY and my husband created an amazing little zen area that was previously barren. The garden is a sanctuary for us to relax in now. The only thing which didn’t go to plan was the installation of the furniture, as it took a while for it to arrive. If we had to do this project again we would order it well in advance as we only received the dining set this week. It’s now in the garage waiting for next year!’ Tom Church, Co-Founder of LatestDeals said: Elizabeth and her husband have managed to create a stunning garden that no doubt increases the value of their property, after waiting nearly two decades to complete the makeover. With dficult areas, sometimes getting a professional in is best - but as Elizabeth has proven, sourcing budget supplies and doing parts of the overall makeover yourself can save you thousands of pounds. I hope this garden lasts them many years to come. title: diy couple transform plain kitchen
story: DIY couple transform plain kitchen into rustic space using £. IKEA bargainsRachel Green, , and her partner Max Butler, , didnt rate their plain cupboards and drab black worktop, so decided to completely transform it on the cheap by sourcing materials from Poundland, Ikea and BQA couple transformed their plain kitchen into a modern, minimalist cooking spaceByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Dec | comments A bargain-hunting couple used smart DIY hacks and clever purchases to completely transform their kitchen into a rustic cooking space. Rachel Green, , and Max Butler, , slashed costs of revamping their brown cupboards and black worktop by hunting for bargains on BQ, Ikea and Facebook Marketplace. Taking it on as a lockdown project, the couple also scrolled through Pinterest to get their inspiration. During lockdown when we were house searching we had a lot more time on our hands, they told bargain site LatestDeals. So I spent hours on Instagram and Pinterest saving pictures of my favourite ideas and creating a mood board for each room.The kitchen had plain brown cupboards and black worktops, so we decided to create more of a monochrome feel with marble effect countertops and matching accessories. We did the whole project on a budget by sourcing items from BQ, IKEA and Facebook Marketplace. They found some of the items they needed at Homebase, including a roller set for £. and two tins of Maison Deco Refresh paint to cover the worktops, cupboards and splash-back. But to jazz it up, they painted their fittings gold. They said: To add a special touch we decided to make all the handles on the wardrobes and drawers gold. We did this by removing them all and spray painting them with a can from Amazon. It cost just £.. They protected the worktops with two rolls of self-adhesive film that they bought at BQ for £. They added: One addition we wanted for the kitchen was some shelves. One of our friends gave us the idea so we could get some cupboard space back, as well as have the ability to rescue some of our nicer ceramic pieces from the back of the cupboards. I’d also seen the idea of a shelf pantry all over Instagram and wanted to recreate it for myself. To find the materials, we searched Facebook Marketplace for people selling scaffolding wood for cheap and we managed to get them for £ a board.  Then we just sanded them slightly, keeping some of the roughness, as that was the look we were going for. We got the brackets off Etsy, and these turned out to be one of the most expensive purchases. We went for some rustic handcrafted brackets made from reclaimed timber and they were £. And they added to the rustic, homely feel by placing items, like an Asda casserole dish for £ and Poundland jars, on top of the wood. They said: Some of the other jars came from IKEA for the pasta, and they were £. each. While we were in IKEA we picked up some faux foliage for the shelves and the tops of the cupboards for around £, and a gold rail for additional wall storage for £. They used sugar soap to wash down the surfaces before sanding them down. By taking off the draw handles, they could spray them gold without causing a mess in the kitchen. They slapped two coats of paint on the skirting boards, ceiling and cupboards. They said: Overall it was very easy to do, it was just time consuming waiting for the paint to dry and hard to get to some of the cupboards to paint them. If we had to do it again, we would take the doors off to complete the job. We had tried to avoid doing this as we thought we might struggle to get them back on. However, it made it a lot harder to paint without getting inside the cupboards too. title: inside queens mail sack 300
story: Exclusive: Inside Queens mail sack - with  letters a day about cats, bus stops and teaReaders share their stories of writing to the Queen and getting a reply, from a request to send a cat a birthday card to an appeal to overhaul bus stops to save a hairdoThe Queen receives sackloads of mail Image: Press AssociationByJulie McCaffrey:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsBuckingham Palace is looking for a first-class royal servant to answer sackloads of mail sent to the Queen. Her Majesty receives around  daily letters from her fans and it is little wonder she needs a hand to reply to each one. The new assistant correspondence officer will help ensure the monarch’s mail receives a prompt and proper response befitting of the royal crest. As the job advertisement says, many of the posted letters are unique. From a request to send a cat a birthday card, an appeal to overhaul bus stops to save a hairdo and adorable children’s drawings, readers share their stories of writing to the Queen and getting a reply. Would you like to come for tea  Jane Frances’s six-year-old daughter Neve was travelling from Merseyside to London in April  to see a theatre show and thought she’d invite the Queen out for tea. Jane says: “I didn’t want to crush Neve’s dream by not posting the letter, even though I never thought we’d get a reply in a million years.  “Neve was ecstatic when she received a reply from Buckingham Palace. Her Majesty respectfully declined Neve’s invitation, which is perhaps inevitable since the day we were in London was Prince William’s wedding day!” I painted a picture of your favourite horse Shane Hagan felt so much affection for the Queen she felt compelled to send her a painting of her horse Sanction. The -year-old, from York, says she “absolutely loves” the monarch and wanted to give her something back after all she has done for our nation. She adds: “I took up painting after corrective eye surgery and, because I know the Queen loves horses, I painted one of her favourites and sent it along with a Christmas card. “I don’t think anyone imagines they’ll receive a letter back from the most famous woman in the world. “So when I received one, thanking me and encouraging me to continue painting, I was chuffed to bits. Now I’m a full-time artist.” Can you cover bus shelters  My mum is fussy about her hair In , nine-year-old Emma Parsons was so annoyed by mum Jeanette’s hairdo being ruined by rain as they stood at a bus stop she decided to do something. “I thought the Queen could sort this out,” she says. “So once I’d dried out at home, I wrote to Her Majesty to ask for help. I askedshe could put seats and roofs on all the bus stops, but to cover our one first. “My dad, Vince, said I’d never get a reply. Two weeks later none of us could believe our eyes when I received a letter from Buckingham Palace.”  The Queen’s lady-in-waiting explained “it is not within the Queen’s control”, but Emma, now , says: “Soon afterwards the bus stop, outside Cardf Castle, was modernised and I have taken full credit for that.” Civil servant Emma adds: “My parents weren’t sentimental, but that letter was kept and I still have it. My grandchildren are very impressed.” My daughter charmed the Queen with her story about the young Princess Elizabeth A teacher was so impressed by Lottie Trewick’s story of the Queen and Princess Margaret playing in the grounds of Buckingham Palace that she sent it to Her Majesty. And -year-old Lottie was thrilled to receive a reply.  Lottie’s mum Karen, from Winchester, Hants, says: “Lottie wrote the story during the Queen’s Diamond Jubilee in  and there was a lot of excitement about the Royal Family. “And she was doubly excited to receive a response.  “The letter says: ‘Her Majesty was pleased to see your charming tale about a mighty oak tree which, in your story, became a great fortress for Princess Elizabeth and Princess Margaret’. “We framed the letter.” Will you send my cat a th birthday card  When Rachel Thomas, of Barmouth in North Wales, heard that the Queen sends cards to those celebrating their th birthday she was keen to remind her not to forget a special centenarian: her cat. Rachel, now , says: “When I was , I realised my -year-old cat Sindy was  in cat years. “So I wrote to Her Majesty asking for a card for my cat. “Her reply said that the Queen can’t send a card to a cat.  “But I was so proud to get a letter from the Queen’s lady-in-waiting that I went around all the classes in my school to show off the letter I had received.” Iaposm worried about koalas Fearing for the impact on wildle during last year’s Australian bushfires, six-year-old Esme Robinson wrote to the Queen to express her concern. Shortly after sending it, the nation was plunged into lockdown and the Queen stayed at Windsor Castle.  Esme, of Herts, lost hope of receiving a reply to her letter sent to Buckingham Palace. A few weeks later she was stunned to receive a special letter franked with the royal stamp. Mum Suzi says: “It was a great moment of excitement at a time when we all had to stay at home.” Get well soon Nine-year-old Summer Wise was off school with Covid in October when she heard the Queen had spent the night in hospital. She wrote to wish her a speedy recovery. Her mum Natasha, of North West London, says: “Summer wrote in her neatest writing and decorated the envelope with stickers and drew a picture of Windsor Castle. Summer told Her Majesty she was also ill and asked her lots of questions.  “She was astounded when she received her reply from Windsor Castle containing a leaflet all about the Queen so she could find the answers to her questions. “We’ll keep the royal reply for ever.” Here’s a chocolate medal  some bunting Three-year-old India Grainger sent Her Majesty a chocolate medal and some bunting to celebrate her diamond jubilee in . Her mum, Hester, from Reading, Berks, says: “India dictated her letter to me and was very specic about what she wanted me to write. She was incredibly excited when we posted it but doubly so to receive a letter back.  “She said she was touched that India had given her a chocolate medal and some flags. And India was over the moon. “The framed letter hangs in our bathroom.” You are the best queen in the whole wide world Keen to bring a smile to the poorly Queen’s face, seven-year-old Chloe Elmer drew her gold and purple crown, her hats and a giant love heart. And in a letter adorned with more hearts and “I love you”, Chloe, of Basingstoke, Hants, wrote: “Dear your majesty, I hope you are fellingbetter. You are the best queen in the wholwide world.” Mum Elizabeth said: “Chloe really wanted Her Majesty to know she was in her thoughts. She even researched the Queen’s favourite colour for the hats. “A few weeks ago we had a letter from the Queen’s lady-in-waiting, thanking Chloe. She was completely shocked and had the biggest smile ever. She’s so proud to know Her Majesty took the time from running the country to write. “Chloe’s letter is a frame on display as a treasure.” We have a race horse you bred Knowing the Queen is passionate about horses, Louise Rowe wrote to give Her Majesty an update one she had bought from her in August . Louise, , from Dorking, Surrey, says: “I wanted to let the Queen know Otago, a horse she had bred, was really happy, doing well and making us proud.  He has won at Epsom twice and I said he had a home for le with us once his career ended. I was thrilled to receive a reply – she wished me well with Otago. The Queen’s letter and card will be treasured for ever.” We are related Student Cameron Holmes wrote to the Queen two years ago to tell Her Majesty: “We’re related.” Cameron, , from Malton, North Yorks, says: “A relative traced our family tree all the way back to the s and discovered that my th great grandfather was King James V of Scotland. I felt I had to let her know.  “Maybe I shouldn’t have been so surprised to receive a reply from Buckingham Palace – we are family, after all.” The letter, which sends Cameron’s family good wishes and includes a genealogical chart of the Kings and Queens of England, is now framed in Cameron’s home. Happy birthday Barnaby Hocking, seven, from Paignton, Devon, made the Queen a nd birthday card while doing art with his dad Dean.  Barnaby’s mum Victoria says: “The day the reply came, with the Buckingham Palace stamp, the postman ran up our drive – he was almost more excited than we were. “We didn’t expect to hear back. For the letter to be so personal means an awful lot. Barnaby was so proud he took his letter to school.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON The QueenBuckingham PalaceRoyal FamilyCivil servantsChristmas cards" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: london uks omicron hotspot variant
story: London is UKs Omicron hotspot with iant making up % of all new casesOmicron makes up % of new Covid cases in London which is the fastest growing area for the iant, along with Scotland, and there are fears more restrictions will be neededShoppers, some wearing face-masks, walk along Oxford Street in central London Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsThe British government is considering tougher restrictions after it has emerged that the rapidly spreading Omicron iant makes up % of new Covid cases in London. Boris Johnson has already introduced his Plan B which is unpopular by many members of his own Conservative Party and those in the business community where Christmas is a key period of the year.Ministers took part in a Cobra meeting on Friday where they looked at what steps can be taken to slow the spread of the Omicron iant, it is reported. Communities Secretary Michael Grove, who himself has tested positive, said that London and Scotland were hotspots and the situation was “deeply concerning”. The new data suggests that Omicron will now become dominant by as early as next week.  Last Christmas, London was badly hit by the Alpha iant and now a year on there is talk over whether similar restrictions to those in place then could be reimposed with all  boroughs having rising cases of Omicron. Data from the Department of Health shows that infections in London rose by .% in the week up to December  which was the quickest of England’s nine regions. There were . infections among , people tested which was the highest since last January. So far it has not been reflected in hospitalisations and deaths but the data typically lags behind by several weeks as it takes time for people to become seriously ill.  Mr Gove, reported the Daily Mail, said: The meeting Iaposve just chaired with first ministers of all the devolved administrations was presented with some very challenging new information.We know that we have the highest number of Covid infections across the UK recorded today since January . We know the Omicron iant is doubling every two to three days in England, and possibly even faster in Scotland. We know that % of reported cases in London are the Omicron iant and of course we only identied Omicron in this country a fortnight ago. On Friday, , new Covid infections and  deaths were reported in the UK within  days of a positive test. A further  Omicron infections were reported bringing the total to ,, according to the latest figures. In England,  additional Omicron cases were reported totalling , overall. One additional case of Omicron has been reported across Scotland which has  confirmed cases of the iant. In Wales, four further cases have been reported with the total number now standing at . No new cases have been reported across Northern Ireland where the number of infections currently remains at three. title: mcdonalds worker posed stockbroker prey
story: McDonalds worker posed as stockbroker to prey on , victims on Sugar Daddy sitesAbdul Elahi traded a terabyte of twisted images and footage - amounting to , hours of video and , photos - in just one saleAbdul Hasib Elahi was jailed for  years Image: SWNSByKelly-Ann MillsReporter:,  Dec One of Britainaposs worst online sexual predators who targeted , people across the world before selling sickening footage as boxsets has been jailed for  years. Abdul Elahi posed as a rich stockbroker on Sugar Daddy websites before blackmailing his victims into performing degrading sexual acts. The -year-old then sold the footage to paedophiles around the world in packaged boxsets - which included young women abusing themselves, siblings and their children. From the sales of his material, he would then launder the money through Amazon gt cards and buy electrical goods to sell on for cash. In one single sale, the McDonaldaposs worker traded a terabyte of twisted images and footage - amounting to , hours of video and , photos. Some of Elahiaposs victims attempted suicide after he uploaded videos of them to porn websites even bragging: Pornhub are going to love this. The warped paedophile previously admitted  online sexual offences after he targeted nearly , victims in  countries between  and . Elahi was branded depraved, abhorrent and callous by a judge as he was jailed for  years with an extended license period of eight years. Sentencing at at Birmingham Crown Court, Judge Sarah Buckingham said: Your offending is prolic and involved at least  victims.  You showed a complete and utter disregard for the welfare of every victim you manipulated irrespective of their age and there was a sadistic element to your offending. Your distribution of images was on a vast scale and allowed you to make money which you then laundered. You used multiple fake online personas to encourage women to perform sexual acts. These were not porn stars bur real women who provided the images. You were sophisticated in your operation. You wiped imagery from your phone , you packaged up these products into boxsets to be sold. There are so many examples of your sadistic and degrading exploitation and blackmail of these women it would take days to cover it all again. Your demands increased in their viciousness and brutality and however much your victims pleaded for mercy you ignored their pleas. Even when they were driven to suicide you sneered in the face of their despair. In my judgement you do pose a signicant risk of members of the public. You are an extremely dangerous inidual. You were motivated by a feeling of power and control over women, you were attracted to the financial reward you could achieve. You were utterly devoid of any empathy and regret for the pain and suffering you inflicted. Whatever your claims you did this for money I am satisfied that you harbour sadistic and paedophilic characteristics and are aroused by the abuse of children along with the abuse of women. You derived pleasure from manipulating, humiliating and distressing your victims. You were totally unmoved by their pleas to be left alone. You were prepared to, and did, offend, You showed no insight or remorse and at the same time breathtaking arrogance. You will remain a danger for some years to come. You are an example of one of the very worst type of predatory offenders ever apprehended thus far. Elahi boasted about his jet-set lestyle and how he used private jets to fly to Los Angeles – in fact, he was living with his parents and working in McDonalds. Prosecutor Andrew Langdale had branded Elahi one of the most serious sexual predators online that has been seen before this court. He added: Elahi is in a league of his own. He taught others how to abuse women and children. “This is child abuse imagery he distributed we argue he is a dangerous predator. “Abuse against others was his full time occupation. Graham Arnold, defending, said: It may be something that means nothing to the victims but he wants me to express his deepest remorse. He pushed people to do depraved things at their own great cost. He is trying to look into himself to see why and it is a very dark place. The truth is that he is struggling to find any light but all I can say on his behalf is that he is trying. Appearing alongside Elahi in the dock was Kirsty Nicholls, , who previously pleaded guilty to two charges of sexual assault of a child and one of making an indecent photo. After Elahiaposs arrest in July , officers from the NCA, the FBI, and Australian and New Zealand police found phone messages between the pair.  Elahi requested that Nicholls abused a young boy, to which she was entirely compliant and even made suggestions on how to carry out the abuse Nicholls, of Northolt, Middlesex, was jailed for six years and nine months today. Judge Buckinghamshire said: It was through Sugar Daddy websites that you encountered Elahi, the very worst type of man. One who used, manipulated and blackmailed vulnerable women to get what he wanted. The dference between you and his victims was that you were willing to do as he asked. You are intelligent and aware what you were doing was horribly wrong and in your own words sick. You became immersed in a sexualised world and became caught up in the world of online sex work without any thought of the implications. news uk-news meghan-markles-first-christmas-gt-"Meghan Markle joins royal family for Sandringham Christmas serviceByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec | commentsChristmas shopping can be hard enough without having to buy for one of the worldaposs most famous women - the Queen.And while spending her first Christmas with now-husband Prince Harry, Meghan Markle had to find a gt for her then-fianceeaposs grandmother.But it appears that Meghan not only stuck to the rule that royal presents should be cheap and cheeky - her gt delighted not only Her Majesty but her dogs too. It was reported that Meghan bought the Queen a singing hamster, which led the monarch to burst out laughing, remarking: It can keep my dogs company. Meanwhile, not only did Meghan impress the Queen during her first Christmas at Sandringham, she also impressed her future brother-in-law, Prince William, with her gt choices.  According to the biography Finding Freedom, she nailed his gt - a spoon with the words aposCereal Killerapos on it. The authors wrote: Meghanaposs biggest challenge was finding the perfect novelty gts to amuse her new extended family. At least one of her gts was a huge hit—a spoon for William that had aposcereal killerapos embossed on the shallow bowl end of the utensil. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Like Meghan, the Duchess of Cambridge was no doubt similarly nervous to Meghan when she spent her first Christmas at Sandringham in . However, rather than hitting the High Street or furiously searching online for a gt for the Queen, Kate came up with an idea for a more personal homemade present - and it appears it went down very well with Her Majesty. Speaking in a documentary to mark the Queenaposs th birthday, Kate revealed what the thoughtful gt was. She explained: I can remember being at Sandringham, for the first time, at Christmas. And I was worried what to give the Queen as her Christmas present. I thought back to what I would give my own grandparents. And I thought, aposIaposll make her something,apos which could have gone horribly wrong. But I decided to make my grannyaposs recipe for chutney. I was slightly worried about it, but I noticed the next day that it was on the table. “I think such a simple gesture went such a long way for me and Iaposve noticed since sheaposs done that on lots of occasions and I think it just shows her thoughtfulness, really, and her care in looking after everybody.
