title: mulled red wine could healthiest
story: Mulled red wine could be the healthiest Christmas tipple, claim expertsMany Brits indulge in a drink over the festive season but those who are keen to be healthier might be interested to know that spiced mulled wine has some health benefitsWe spoke to health experts about Christmas drinking Image: Getty Images WestendBySophie FosterLestyle  Travel ReporterRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsOver the next few weeks, most of us will be celebrating the festive season with party after party. Whether it’s the Christmas work do, a dinner party with friends or a pre-th present swap there’s bound to be lots of merry events. And, unless you’re tee-total you’re probably going to have a tipple or two . But, as we know, alcohol can affect our health in a number of ways – not least including the damage to your liver. If you do want to have a drink over the Christmas period, we’ve spoken to doctors and experts to find out the best options.  Canapost see the sign-up box  Click here. And, it seems mulled wine is a winner.Hussein Abdeh, Clinical Director and Superintendent Pharmacist at Medicine Direct, said: “When it comes to Christmas time, there aren’t many more festive drinks than mulled wine, but did you know that it also has a number of evidence-based health benefits.“Mulled wine is made from red wine, which is known to contain compounds called polyphenols. These compounds are loaded with antioxidants that aid in keeping your blood vessels flexible, which helps the heart to pump blood around the body more easily. “This reduces the risk of clotting and helps to take some strain off the heart. Furthermore, polyphenols help to keep HDLin your blood. “The cinnamon contained in mulled wine is also packed with antioxidants which can help with the physical signs of ageing by reducing oxidative stress in the body.“Cinnamon is also an effective anti-inflammatory and can help to reduce the risk of inflammatory conditions such as Arthritis and IBS Irritable bowel syndrome . This spice can help to reduce levels of ‘bad’ cholesterol while keeping the good cholesterol at a stable level.“The cloves in red wine are able to control your blood sugar levels, which is a serious health benefit as prolonged s of time with high blood sugar can increase the risk of cardiovascular disease.”Experts over at Optibac Probiotics added: “Drink vegan red wine. The presence of plant polyphenols in vegan red wine is believed to be particularly signicant: polyphenols have been shown to have numerous health benefits, thought to be due to their ‘prebiotic’ properties.“And, vegan guts will be grateful for the higher intake of healthy plant nutrients! The good news is that vegan red wine is a great source of polyphenols!” Soyou’re looking for a tipple with health benefits then vegan mulled wine could be for you.It should be noted that mulled wine can be high in calories and soyouaposre looking for a lower-calorie alternative opt for light spirits like vodka with low-calorie mixers or even an alcoholic spritzer like Two Brooks which has  calories a can. However, it’s important to note that alcohol is still never healthy. The NHS advises drinking no more than  units of alcohol per week. If you are worried about your drinking or find it dficult to stop then head to drinkaware for further resources or contact your GP for advice and support.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON AlcoholChristmas party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum finds 5000 aldi chocolate
story: Mum finds £, in Aldi chocolate bar and there are  golden tickets still up for grabsSupermarket Aldi has hidden  golden tickets inside their Dairyfine Golden Giveaway Chocolate Bars - and there are still  more to find across the countrySian Walker found a golden ticket Image: AldiByKelly-Ann MillsReporterKieran Isgin:,  Dec | commentsA mum who bought a chocolate bar while shopping with her son was shocked to find a golden ticket inside worth an amazing £, inside. Supermarket Aldi has hidden  golden tickets inside their Dairyfine Golden Giveaway Chocolate Bars - and there are still  more to find. The tickets are worth either £, or £, and are in stores across the country. Sian Walker, from Nantwich, says the prize will mean she can build a dream extension. The -year-old said she was aposjokingapos with her son and pretended they had won - little did they know there was a genuine golden ticket inside the chocolate bar.  She said: “I couldn’t believe it. I first picked up one of the smaller bars of chocolate then swapped it for the larger one to share with my son. We were joking around pretending we had won and then when we opened it up it was such a surprise to see the golden ticket inside.  “It’s such an amazing gt and has come just in time for helping us build our dream extension on our home. Thank you so much Aldi, this really is going to make such a big dference!” All you have to do to be in for a chance of winning visit and Aldi store and buy a giant bar of Dairyfine Milk Chocolate. title: mum makes 6ft christmas decoration
story: Mum makes ft Christmas decoration using cardboard - after seeing £ version onlineAngela Jones used postal tubes, feather boas and tester paints to create her le sized nutcracker which came in at a fraction of the priceThe nutcracker is made from postal tubes and feather boas, costing just £ Image: FacebookByLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Dec | commentsA savvy mum has created an enormous Christmas nutcracker from postal tubes after being inspired by a £ version online. Angela Jones spent little more than £ to create her own version of the toy soldier which stands at ft tall.The DIY whizz, of Bolton in Greater Manchester, used tester paints and accessories bought on eBay to decorate the festive figurine, helping to keep costs down.Its body was built with postal tubes while feather boas were used to create its hair and iconic hat. Angela shared her tips on social media with a photo of her le sized nutcracker next to her stunning Christmas tree, showered with pink satin ribbons and oversized baubles.  Its tunic was painted in baby pink to match her overall colour scheme. Iaposve seen nutcrackers selling for £ plus and I manage to make this all in for around £, she said in her post. Showing its size against my tree which is ft. Thousands of fellow Christmas enthusiasts praised the mum for her creation and her money saving tips. One person said: Wow, thataposs great. title: new baby joy woman who
story: Woman who became one of UKs youngest mums aged  is expecting another babyTressa Middleton hit the headlines when it was revealed she was pregnant despite being barely out of primary school - before it emerged she had been raped by her brotherTressa pictured with new baby Arihanna Young and new dad Darren Young at the Norton House Hotel near Edinburgh Image: Daily RecordByEmily Hall:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec One of Britainaposs youngest ever mums - who gave birth at just  after being raped by her own brother - has revealed she is expecting another baby girl. Tressa Middleton was raped by her own brother and became pregnant in  when she was barely out of primary school The baby was later taken away and Tressa spiralled into depression and drug use as she fought to come to terms with her horric ordeal. But she has since turned her le around with partner Darren Young and the couple revealed this week that she is around  weeks pregnant with another daughter with him. Posting a scan pic, Darren said on Facebook on December : Itaposs another girl - Arihanna is absolutely delighted.Arihanna is the coupleaposs first daughter, born weighing lbs oz in October  after a -hour labour. Tressa hit the headlines  years ago when it was revealed she was expecting a baby aged just . She had suffered a damaged childhood - her mum Tracey Tallons struggled with addiction and Tressa was forced to endure late night parties. Her older brother Jason sexually abused her from the age of seven and she fell pregnant by him when he raped her four years later.  She kept the identity of the babyaposs father a secret and the pair were taken into care until - aged  - she broke down and told a social worker what had really happened. It led to her daughter being taken away from her and then adopted in . Jason,  at the time, was jailed for four years in  after a DNA test proved Tressa was telling the truth. Tressa, of Bathgate, West Lothian, Scotland, has spoken of her upset that she was unable to keep her first baby. She told the Sunday Mirror in : Arihanna will always know she has a big sister. I talk to her about it now, even though she canapost understand. Sheaposll never be a secret. They are polar opposites - Arihanna is smiley and contented, while my other daughter was vocal and feisty. But I just know theyaposd get on.  I tell Arihannaher sister was here theyaposd play games together. I really hope that one day they can meet. It would mean the world to me. In the meantime all I want is for Arihanna to have a normal childhood, where she knows she is loved and safe. And she added: I felt pure joy the moment Arihanna was born. There were times I thought Iaposd never have another baby. But I also feel guilty, because Arihanna is with me and my older daughter is not. An -year-old is believed to be the youngest ever mother in the UK after she had a child in June this year. title: revellers pack out bars festive
story: Revellers pack out bars for festive fun on last Friday before vaccine passportsPubs and bars were packed in towns and cities around the country on Friday as revellers enjoyed festive fun with fears tougher Covid restrictions are ahead due to the Omicron surgeRevellers have hit towns and cities across the UK in large numbersImage: NB PRESS LTDByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsBrits flocked to bars and nightclubs for Christmas drinks on the last Friday before vaccine passports and amid fears these venues could face tougher curbs.With Boris Johnson already having introduced a Plan B to tackle the new Omicron iant, there have also been reports that the government is now considering a Plan C with stfer measures. This could mean face masks in all enclosed public spaces, theof an NHS app with check-ins for bars and restaurants, and vaccine passports for more venues.While they are reportedly being planned for January, scientists have said that they need to come in as early as next weekhospitalisations aren’t to swamp the NHS. It led to many revellers heading out in towns and cities across the country with even queues gathering outside some popular venues on Thursday and Friday night.  At the same time, work Christmas parties have been in full flow with people having a fun time with their colleagues. The prime minister gave the go ahead for the parties although there has been advice that people should be tested. Johnson said: We donapost want nativity plays to be cancelled. We think thataposs okay. Currently on what we can see, keep going with Christmas parties but obviously everybody should exercise caution.  Have ventilation, wash your hands and getting a test before you go is the sensible thing to do to give everybody  at the party the confidence that the person youaposre meeting is not contagious. Ministers took part in a Cobra meeting on Friday where they looked at what steps can be taken to slow the spread of the Omicron iant, it is reported. Data from the Department of Health shows that infections in London rose by .% in the week up to December  which was the quickest of England’s nine regions.  There were . infections among , people tested which was the highest since last January. So far it has not been reflected in hospitalisations and deaths but the data typically lags behind by several weeks as it takes time for people to become seriously ill. Public health officials are advising that eventhe rapidly spreading Omicron iant causes less serious illness than Delta, it could lead to , people being admitted to NHS hospitals per day.Health SecretarySajid Javidwas given a presentation from the UK Health Security Agencythis week where he was told that “stringent action” would be needed on or before December the iant’s doubling time stays at . days,reported.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Omicron iant" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news teacher-lives-more--spiders-"Ian Wileman inspects one of his  spidersByDanny RiggGraeme Murray:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA teacher lives with more than , spiders after the tragic loss of his we. Ian Wileman, , said that his huge collection helped pick him up after losing his beautul primary school teacher we, Michelle. He was forced to make the heart-breaking decision to end le support for his best friend Michelle, .Michelle died after a combination of the influenza virus and scarlet fever led to her contracting sepsis in March, .Ian has collected spiders since he was , but found himself struggling to look after them following the tragedy.Ian told the Liverpool Echo : When I was really not good, shortly after Michelle died, I actually went in the room and found a couple of them had died because Iaposd forgot to water them.I was really gutted, because obviously I wasnapost in a great place, and then losing a couple of animals because I hadnapost gone in and watered them properly, I just felt really guilty.I was in a situation where I thought, aposIaposve got to move them onapos. Five months later, he drove his son Billy to the pet shop so they could match their male with someone aposs female for breeding. But Billy realised this meant the end of their spider collection Ian said: On the way home, Bill was - at the time, he was eight or nine - and he was really upset that there were going to be no more spiders.  So I said, aposOh, weaposll get a couple moreapos. The eight-legged friends have been a huge part of Ianaposs le for decades and without them, he may never have met his we. In his early s, Ian was an iconic animal man who visited schools with spiders and the other animals he had at the time, taking his collection as far as Halax, West Yorkshire. A visit to a primary school in Speke, near Liverpool also planted the thought of going into teaching.  The teachers there just kept saying, aposYouaposve got an aptitude with these kids. The kids love you. Wouldnapost you think about doing it full time  Ian met Michelle in  while they were both training to be teachers at university. On their first date, he jokingly told Michelle he would marry her. He said: She was a beautul, lovely, caring woman. She was everything to me, we were best friends. When she died in March , Ian promised Michelle that he would raise their then-eight-year-old son Billy to be a man with good morals and ethics.  We spent quite a long time on our knees. Le was pretty dire for quite a long time. But these animals kind of give you something , you know, youaposve got , lives in that room that need you to keep them alive. He added: Itaposs a big part of my le. I donapost know what Iaposd doIaposd never had them. Ian also shares his hobby with his son Billy. Around  spiders in his collection of , across belong to Billy, who bought them with his own pocket money. Ian said: Heaposs really, really keen on it.  Itaposs a big part of his le now as well, which shows in the fact that heaposs buying his own and growing his own. I donapost go near it. The spiders heaposs bought out of his pocket money are his. I have nothing to do with them. He looks after them. He feeds them. He waters them. He pots them on when they need potting on. Itaposs down to him to do that. They keep their collection in a room heated between  and  degrees celsius. Both spend hours watching them and looking out for signs that they need feeding, or are shedding their skin, or are ready for breeding. He said: They all have absolutely incredible markings on them. Itaposs like keeping little works of art. They are absolutely amazing things.  He finds it infuriating spiders are portrayed as scary creatures when they are amazing and beautul and worthy of protection. The worst species of spider out there that youaposre allowed to keep, Iaposve got  of them in this house, he said. And theyaposve got medically signicant venom, sothey bit you, itaposs going to hurt, youaposre going to be in pain. Nobody has ever, in the whole history of mankind, been killed by a tarantula bite. Ian added: Thereaposs no reason for anyone to say negative things about them. There are enough people scared of them. Work and his son aside, Ian spends the vast majority of his time with his pets and finds solace in that room in his house. He said: A thousand animals take quite a signicant chunk of your le to look after. But itaposs not a chore, and it never is a chore, because itaposs fascinating to be with them. Theyaposre amazing things. Theyaposre incredible. title: teen begged mum calm down
story: Girl, , begged mum to calm her down in final call before her deathAimee Devenney, , from Letterkenny, Co Donegal, Ireland, told her mum Michelle, Mammy I need you to calm me down when she felt an asthma attack coming on last DecemberAimee Devenney died from an asthma attack while staying with her grandparents Image: RIP.ieByMatthew DreschReporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA mother has shared her daughteraposs final heartbreaking words to her before she died from an asthma attack. Aimee Devenney, from Letterkenny, Co Donegal, Ireland, told her mum Michelle aposMammy I need you to calm me downapos when she felt the attack coming on last December.The -year-old rang her mother for help while staying with her grandparents and later collapsed at the scene, the Irish Mirror reports.She was rushed to hospital however medical staff were not able to save the schoolgirl, despite working on her for two and a half hours. Michelle told Barrscéalta on RTÉ Raidió that her daughter would sometimes suffer a panic attack when she felt an asthma attack coming on. Her daughteraposs request for help was the last time she spoke to her. The mum explained: “They worked on her for a long time. They told me in the hospital that normally they only work on a case like this for twenty minutes, but that they had worked on her for two and a half hours, so I knew they had done everything they possibly could to save her.” And Michelle said that the family are now determined to honour Aimeeaposs memory - starting a fundraiser for two important charities, with over €, raised so far. She continued: We decided to collect money for two charities, the Asthma Society of Ireland, because people don’t know enough about asthma and how dangerous it can be, and Pieta House in Letterkenny. “Aimee spent some time with them, she suffered a lot with her mental health. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter You would never think it, because she was always so happy go lucky, but they helped her through a really tough time and I’d like to give something back.. The heartbroken mum said her kind daughter would be proud of the work her family is now doing in her name. Michelle added: “She was very good at music and drama, like her grandad. She was very kind and always had a smile on her face. She’d be very proud of the work we’re doing to help these charities.”You can donate to the GoFundMe page HERE. title: thorpe park announces new rollercoaster
story: Thorpe Park announces new rollercoaster for  - and it could be tallest in UKThe Old Town area of Thorpe Park will be the home for the new rollercoaster but the resort has confirmed it is examining what best to do with the current rides situated on the siteThorpe Park already boasts an impressive resume when it comes to rollercoasters including Swarm, pictured Image: Daniel LewisByRobert Edwards:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsThorpe Park has announced plans for a brand new rollercoaster which will become the tallest in the UK, according to a website dedicated to theme park rides. The Surrey-based theme park already boasts an impressive resume when it comes to rollercoasters including both Stealth and Swarm - the last to open at the resort in .However, Thorpe Parkaposs proposed latest addition - which could be ready for  - would undoubtedly become the star attraction, reports Surrey Live.According to RideRater, the proposals were initially unveiled at a special in-person presentation for local residents on Thursday. The online website also reports that the ft rollercoaster would be the tallest in the UK, beating the ftabove ground record held by the Big One at Blackpool Pleasure Beach since .  Now further details have been shared online via the Thorpe Park website and members of the public are being asked to submit their feedback on the proposals via a public consultation. It is holding a public consultation that closes on January ,  allowing members of the public to submit feedback on the proposals. The resort said in a statement: The Covid- pandemic has had, and continues to have, a signicant impact on admission numbers to the Resort. Thorpe Park Resort aims to continue to invest in the Park’s attractions to encourage more people toto the Resort now that the tourism industry has re-opened. This key investment and the introduction of new attractions is critical to the Resort’s recovery from the Covid-related impacts on the business. With this in mind, we are delighted to announce that we are proposing to add an exciting new rollercoaster to Thorpe Park Resort’s portfolio of world-class attractions. This will be the first new rollercoaster at Thorpe Park since the arrival of THE SWARM in . news uk-news uks-biggest-family-radfords-show-"Radford Family enjoys ‘North Pole’ breakfast and advent calendarsByAlice Peacock:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Pancakes, pastries and chocolate Santas were on the menu for a festive “ North Pole ’ themed breakfast at the Radfords, Britain’s largest family, to kick off the festive season. Sue Radford, who has  children with her husband Noel, organised a breakfast to welcome Santa’s elves to their huge -bedroom home in Morecambe, Lancashire.Sue and Noel, , are parents to Chris, , Sophie, , Chloe, , Jack, , Daniel, , Luke, , Millie, , Katie, , James, , Ellie, , Aimee, , Josh, , Max, , Tillie, , Oscar, , Casper, nine, Hallie, six, Phoebe, five, Archie, four, Bonnie, three, and Heidie, one.Sue frequently chronicles the lives of her hefty brood on Instagram and Youtube.In a video shared to the family’s popular YouTube channel, Sue says good morning to her viewers as well as wishing them a “happy first of December”. She turns the camera around to show that one of her younger children is up early with her, dressed in sweet Christmas pyjamas and putting the finishing touches on a huge tree.Sue proceeds to move through the children’s bedrooms, waking them up for them to move out, bleary eyed, to a dining table laden with Christmas cheer.There are stacks of advent calendars - a dferent one for each child - as well as Christmas crackers, plates piled with pancakes, fruit and chocolate croissants, and chocolate santas. In the middle of the table, three toy elves were sitting on a sleigh, which had a balloon attached to it reading: “Special elf delivery to: The Radfords, From: Santa”. As the kids filter into the Radford’s dining room, chaos ensues. While a couple of the kids seem to have tunnel vision for the candy canes laid on the table, most of them are fixated on the fact Santa has brought three elves with him, one more than in previous years. One of the older children asked: “Who wants to name it ”, which led to the younger children all shouting out suggestions. Eventually, the clan decided on the name “Sprinkles”.  The kids get stuck into their choccy milk, Christmas crackers and their breakfast, while Sue moves around the table handing out their respective advent calendars, which appear to be tailored to each child’s taste. They range from a Body Shop advent calendar for one of the older girls, to a gourmet truffle advent calendar for Sue and Noel to share. Eventually Sue moves away from videoing the joy around the breakfast table to do a one-on-one chat with the camera about what  had been going on that morning. In a segment occasionally interrupted by a crying child and a pooch beside her on the couch, she talks about one of the kids’ PE days as well as a panic over not being able to find Hallie and Phoebe’s school trousers.  With the older kids having left for school, Sue then moves around the home showing some more festive scenes, including a Santa sack for each of her children, hanging across a fire place. Sue and Noel Radford have previously said they are proud of the fact that they keep their family going without relying on benefits. Instead, the stars of the Channel  series  Kids and Counting look after their whopping clan with the proceeds from their pie shop and YouTube channel. The sheer logistical enormity of running the Radford family has made them popular and captivating watching. Recently Sue showed off her home after she and her partner Noel put trees up in their living room, kitchen and on their front porch to feel the festive spirit. She wrote on Instagram : “Christmas has landed in the Radford house.”For previous Christmas celebrations, each Radford child has around £-£ spent on them, costing their parents over £, in gts. To make sure there are no mix-ups on the day, Sue has bought each of them a personalised sack to keep them all in. Sue hand wraps each gt she buys and it has previously been reported she can wrap around  presents every  minutes. She and Noel get through around  rolls of wrapping paper each year to cater for their massive brood. The Radfords have Christmas food to budget for too, with just the festive food costing another £. Britainaposs largest family recently welcomed a brand-new addition to their already huge family, as Sue announced that her eldest son Chris has become a father for the third time. Sue and Noel recently claimed that they have spent more than £ million raising their  children. news uk-news young-aldi-fan--loves-"Aldi store give five-year-old his own unorm after working a ‘sht’ByRuaraidh GilmourGraeme Murray:,  Dec | commentsA five-year-old boy did a sht at Aldi after his mum posted pictures of him tiding up his local branch. Rupert Knight was invited to come and do a bit of work with the managers at the budget supermarket chain which even gave him his own unorm and badge. The youngsteraposs mum Kirsty Knight had posted photographs of her son cleaning up rubbish from the aisles on social media and was later asked by the storeaposs area manager to come in. The store in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, surprised the schoolboy with his own navy Aldi unorm and Rupert, Store Assistant name badge, when he visited them. He was then shown around the store and warehouse before helping to recycle Aldi packaging. An excited Rupert was then even shown how to work the tills. In an adorable video, the youngster can be seen rearranging cans in one of the aisles and removing empty packaging. At the end of his sht, he was awarded a star customer service badge by one of the managers.Kirsty posted adorable pictures of Rupert during his visit on Facebook later on that day , writing: When your five-year old gets a job at Aldi.The post received over , likes and over  comments. One Aldi worker said: I love this, he looks so smart, my kids dress up in my Aldi unorm too at home. Could we ask for a transfer to my store please  Another said: I see potential Employee of the Month awards coming. He looks so happy, love this photo. One member of the group added: Oh my, what a heartbreaker. Adorable. And another said: How cute.  Can learn so much at a young age, plus Iaposd love being a shopper and having this wee friendly gentleman to help me. Well done, lovely. Kirsty said: Rupert has been telling me for months he works at Aldi. Every time I go shopping he has to come to do some work, and by that he means getting rid of all the cardboard. If there isnapost an empty cage he will ask a member of the team to grab him one. Aldi contacted me to invite Rupert into their Mansfield store to meet the store manager and area manager. They got him the t-shirt and badge with his name on, plus a customer service star. Rupert was shown around the store in the office, in the warehouse, in the big fridge and freezers and in the staff room where he found a big bag of Christmas treats just for him. Kirsty added: The customers thought he was super cute and some commented saying aposthey start them young hereapos and things like aposis he on an apprenticeship apos Rupert said he loved everything about working at Aldi. He even got to try out a till. news us-news schoolgirl--gets-adopted-former-"Girls sweet adoption after being adopted by former teacherByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA young girl has been adopted by her former teacher in a real-le Matilda story. Loralie Henry, , has spent more than half of her le in foster care in Los Angeles, Calornia, in the US. She was first put into foster care when she was four before briefly going back to her biological mum and ing to the system aged six. Loralie said: It was actually really scary, too. I didnapost know what to expect in other homes or what they would feed me. I didnapost really know what to do. So I thought, aposWell, what should I do  Is there anyone waiting for me apos I was really scared. Until I met my mom. My second-grade teacher.  Zoe Henry is a teacher and didnapost have any plans to adopt. The single mum says the moment she saw Loralie two years ago she knew she wanted to adopt her.She added to KABC : She came into my class, and I just took one look at her - her little freckles, her little birthmark.I am going to adopt this little girl. Sheaposs my daughter. The minute I set eyes on her.  Zoe thought the little girl would get adopted by another family, but when that didnapost happen she begged social workers to let her adopt. Loralie went to Zoeaposs house two days later. The schoolgirl said: I remember the moment when we were sitting by the car, sheaposs like, aposYouaposre going to come with me.apos I was so surprised and happy. It was like an early present.  Zoe said Loralie has a lot of obstacles but now she is a brave and strong little girl. She added: She is probably the most compassionate person I know. She wants to be a foster mom someday and adopt kids. On November , which is National Adoption Day in the US, Loralie and  other kids were officially adopted by their forever families.  Zoe added: Biological parents have the right to contest. That did not happen. I know her mom really loves her. I know she really wanted to be a better part of her le. But like I tell Loralie, her mom loved her so much that she would let her be adopted so that I can give her what she needed.Matilda is a  American film based on the  Ronald Dahlaposs novel with the same.The young girl has psychokinetic abilities and comes from a disruptive family.During the film, Matilda forms a close bond with her teacher Honey - who goes on to adopt her at the end. title: unvaccinated woman 30 loses arms
story: Unvaccinated woman, , loses arms and legs to Covid as mum makes jab pleaHospital worker Paige Davis, from Colorado Springs, Colorado, has shared how her adult daughter Candices limbs were amputated after she caught Covid and suffered permanent damage to her arms and legsCandice Davis in hospital with her mother Paige Davis and brother Image: NewsflashByLee BullenMatthew DreschReporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments An unvaccinated woman lost her arms and legs after catching coronavirus, prompting her mum to call on people to get the jab.Hospital worker Paige Davis, from Colorado Springs, Colorado, said her adult daughter Candiceaposs limbs were amputated after she was ravaged by Covid. The -year-old was placed on a le support machine after being hospitalised in Philadelphia on August . She suffered permanent damage to her arms and legs - reportedly caused by poor circulation - and doctors had to amputate the limbs to save her le. Ms Davis said her son also caught Covid, however he was vaccinated and made a quick recovery. Speaking about her daughter, she added: Her goal was to get the vaccination, but she just didnapost get to it. So, she wasnapost vaccinated and it took out her heart.  She lost one arm below the elbow, the other arm above the elbow, one leg below the knee, and a half a foot on the right. I didnapost think Covid could take limbs. The young womanaposs condition is improving and her mother shared images of her reading the Bible in her hospital bed. Ms Davis said: She hurts, sheaposs going through it, she beats herself up. She cries more than all of us, but sheaposs the strongest link between the both of us because of what happened to her.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter The mother also urged citizens to get the Covid jab: I just wish everybody would get the shot, my thing is what have you got to lose. According to reports, Candice will soon be fitted with prosthetic limbs ahead of a long period of physiotherapy and recovery. Her brother Starr may also need to consider relocating to a more accessible home for them to live in Philadelphia when she leaves hospital. It comes after another Covid patient, Autumn Nugent, , lost both her hands and feet as after suffering complications caused by coronavirus. Her doctor Dr Wesley Ely from Nashville, US, tweeted: Covid took her hands and feet. Covid- is a disease of blood vessels that can affect your lungs, heart, brain, or any organ. Blood clotting sucks le from vital organs. “This patient asked to have her story shared so that others may learn and seek vaccination.” The medic explained that complications from the virus caused blood clots in Autumnaposs arms and legs, resulting in wounds that resembled burns. news us-news youtuber-finds-remains-teens-who-"Tennessee: Diver discusses finding vehicle of people missing since ByChiara FiorilloNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsAn American YouTuber has found the remains of two teenagers who disappeared in Tennessee  years ago.Jeremy Sides regularly goes scuba-ing in rivers and lakes in a bid to solve missing person cases.In his latest discovery, he found a car that matched the one driven by Erin Foster, , and Jeremy Bechtel, , who disappeared in April . The teens vanished after leaving Fosteraposs home and their whereabouts have been unknown since. But police in Sparta, White County, confirmed the YouTuberaposs discovery matched the car driven by the teens. Mr Sides shared a video on his YouTube channel aposExploring with Nugapos and said he was lost for words when he found the car.  He said: When I saw two teens went missing and vanished in a car, that really stood out to me. When I looked at the town where they were last seen, I saw that a big river ran through it. That just told me to go. The YouTuberaposs first search was unsuccessful, according to reports. But it all changed after one of the manaposs videos was brought to the attention of White County Sherf Steve Page, who then contacted him to suggest looking at a dferent location along the Calfkiller River.  In a video published at the end of November, Mr Sides described the moment he found a car underwater. He said: Whoa, oh OK, thataposs % a car in front of my face. Iaposve been looking all day, and I finally found a car. The police said officers rushed to the scene as soon as Mr Sides called them, and following an investigation, they confirmed the vehicle matched the one driven by the missing teenagers. Mr Sides said the discovery was overwhelming and, even though he was glad that it could bring closure to the teensapos families, he was sad as it meant they had lost their lives. He added: They have been underwater for  years and no one can come and find them is a very sad situation. We observed that all the windows of the vehicle were open.  Probably the young person driving the vehicle, he lost control of the steering wheel and caused the car to fall into the river. Authorities said the remains located in the car have yet to be officially identied and information will be released in due course. Details of how the car ended up in the river are unclear, but officers think the pair lost control of the car and went into the water as there was no guard rail along the road in . Major John Meadows, the lead investigator in the case, said the teens were his classmates, adding it was humbling to be able to help their families find an answer to their mysterious disappearance. Sherf Page told The Washington Post : We have gone in wells, dug up areas, we have used ground-penetrating equipment looking for bodies.[But] it was right under our noses the whole time. … It’s heart-wrenching to know it was that simple, and it was made that hard because of all the rumours and horror stories through the years. The pairaposs disappearance sparked several theories around Tennessee, with some people suggesting they were murdered, while others claimed they had run away to another state. Following the discovery, Sherf page added: I made a promise to the [Foster] family that as long as I was Sherf I’d be looking for these two kids. I did. I have. Mr Betchelaposs father Ronnie said the discovery of the car made him feel like he had lost his son all over again, adding: It just shattered my heart again. We always kind of thought through the years that something happened, but I just didn’t know what. Mr Sides said: I was very humbled that I could just help out. I would like to think the police did what they could. But this one just slipped through the cracks. news weird-news crafty-dachshund-pup-squeezes-through-"Dachshund climbs through stair gate to escape upstairsByChloe Bowen:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA miniature dachshund was so determined to get upstairs to find her owner, she found an incredible way to defeat a stair gate and cardboard barrier designed to stop her. Fteen-month-old dachshund Nala followed her heart and managed to squeeze her way through a narrow gap in the gate. She also maneuvered her way over a large cardboard barrier that was there to make it extra dficult. The loyal puppy wanted to find owner Kiera Vernon, , who was upstairs at the time. Meanwhile, Kiera’s mum, Denise Vernon, caught the puppy in the act and captured it on video. It wasnapost the first time the Vernon family, from Wallasey in Wirral, Merseyside, spotted Nala making bold acrobatic moves. As an attempt to protect her back and stop her climbing, Denise put the strip of cardboard as an barrier and hoped that it would stop her.  But the skilled puppy can climb fairly high for her small size, and is willing to give any challenge a go. Denise, , said: “Nala just wants to be upstairs with my daughter Kiera, and tries everything to get up to see her. She loves Kiera to bits and won’t leave her side whenever she’s at home.” In the video, Nala can be seen pushing her back legs in an attempt to get over the cardboard. With a few kicks she gets over to the other side and takes no hesitation in rushing upstairs to Kiera.  Denise was worried that the amount of climbing would damage her back. Luckily there is an even bigger strip of cardboard put in place to keep Nala downstairs now, which seems to have stopped the sneaky pup’s antics – at least for the time being. For Simba, who also watched Nala’s escape act, and the other family dog, Reggie, there was no hope of them getting upstairs. The TeamDogs Christmas Gt Guide, sponsored by Keep Wales Tidy, is packed with more than  treats, toys, gadgets and garments to make every dog’s tail wag with holly jolly joy on December . Weaposve tried and tested many of the gts on our own TeamDogs friends so you can ensure they’re worth placing under the tree for your most special member of the family. To download our Christmas Gt Guide for free simply subscribe to the TeamDogs newsletter. Denise said: “We got this gate made to measure as Simba could jump normal baby gates. But I was amazed at Nala. We just want to protect her back. “I see little cute sausage stoppers for the bottom of stairs that everyone seems to rave about, but Nala would easily find a way of getting up the stairs.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TeamDogsBabiesDogs" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man convinced hes discovered mummy
story: Man convinced hes discovered a mummy in citys oldest graveyardThe man found a mysterious box wrapped inside a tree that had been felled and inside was a mysterious bundle - he took to social media to ask opinionsThe man found the strange object hidden in the Evergreen Cemetery in L.A Image: GettyByEmily Sleight:,  Dec | commentsA man is convinced that he has stumbled across a mummy in Evergreen Cemetery, the oldest graveyard in Los Angeles, US. The graveyard was established back in  making his discovery feel even creepier.He shared the video to TikTok and got over  thousand likes from users who were seriously intrigued by the discovery.The man, named Tarpit, said: “Yikes, look what I found, they felled this tree in the graveyard and I’m here picking up sticks and chips to burn in my kiln. “This is the oldest graveyard in L.A, what is this  We’re opening it right now.” Tarpit focused the camera onto the small box which appeared to be tied up, containing something wrapped up inside. He continued: “It’s all wrapped up, is that a mummy ” after prodding the mysterious object with a small stick. The small figurine-type object appears to be bound with thread or string, and looks like it has been burnt. Tarpit said: “Okay I have seen what I needed to see. Itaposs something tiny all wrapped up in string. And weaposre going to put it back to rest, donapost you think  Many TikTok users have dferent theories as to what this object might be, with one user even claiming it could be a fetus. One user commented: “People used to do that with babies that were miscarried. They would bind them and stick them in trees. Pretty sure that is what you found.” But others had dferent theories as to what it is, with one user claiming that Tarpit had just opened ‘black magic’. It’s safe to say that the internet was pretty creeped out, with many people warning the man about even touching the object. Some were pretty peeved at Tarpit for touching and moving the object, so much so that he felt the need to make a part  video. In the second part, he reburies the object properly out of respect, just in case the ‘mummy’ is an actual person. He said: “On the off chance that there is a person in there, which is not my bet, we’re going to rebury it better.” He concluded: “If it gets exposed again, I’ve bought string and superglue and we’re going to find a nice spot for it. “I’m not going to go and exhume it again, on the off chance that it is human remains I will keep an eye on it.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Dignity Funerals" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mathematician shows how secret santa
story: Mathematician shows how Secret Santa may not be so secret after allIn a video Dr. Hannah Fry discusses how the likelihood of someone picking their own name for a Secret Santa is quite high - however she has a clever solutionThere are a few mathematical failures in the way we do our Secret Santa [stock image] Image: GettyByEmily Sleight:,  Dec | commentsSecret Santa gives those involved the perfect excuse to buy any old gt and remain anonymous in the process - or at least thataposs what we thought. The task is already dficult enough when those taking part don’t know each other well, often choosing bubble bath and wine as a last resort. Mathematician Dr. Hannah Fry discusses the many mathematical issues that may occur during Secret Santa in a video by Numberphile. From anonymity violations to derangements, it turns out there’s a fair bit of maths behind the festive fun. She said: “There are fundamental things that you need for the perfect Secret Santa, one is total anonymity and two is that everyone should have an equal probability of being selected. According to Dr. Hannah Fry, the normal way of organising Secret Santa by selecting names out of a hat, fails on both fronts. She explains: “Everybody writes their own name on a piece of paper and drops it into a bowl in the middle.  “That bowl is passed around the table and people pick up names, butthey pull out their own name, they read it and put it back. “By doing that,the last person picks out their own name, how do you solve it without violating the rule of anonymity ” In a nutshell, the last Secret Santa member wouldn’t be able to swap with anyone  without finding out who was buying them a present. Hannah continued: “If you have  people sat round a table, there’s a four per cent chance of them choosing their own name. “It all depends on where you’re sitting around that table, which is where you’re looking for a derangement.” A derangement is defined as ‘a permutation of the elements of a set’, and in this case, will ensure no one picks their own name. Hannah explains: “Say you’ve got three people, A, B and C, say there are six ways that this can be reordered, there are only two extra permutations that could work for Secret Santa.  “The problem is,they’re sitting around a table in order ABC, someone is bound to pick their own name.” So, how exactly does Secret Santa worksomeone is bound to pick their own name  It’s all down to the order in which you’re sat at the table, according to maths-whizz, Fry. She continues: “Say A picks first, B picks second and C goes third. If A picks up their own name they’re going to replace it. “They can only pick two things, B or C. If A picks B, now it’s B’s go, so it’s not going to be an issue for B. “However,A has picked B, and B has picked A, there’s only one person for C to pick, and it’s themselves!” As a solution, everyone involved could wait until the end until they look at who they’ve got and start againthey pick themselves. But according to Hannah, this technique has a  per cent chance of failing and a five per cent of failing more than three times in a row.She added: “At this point, everybody is probably going to be less keen to buy each other presents and want to call it a day. Don’t worry too much though, as there is a solution that’s bound to give you the ‘perfect’ Secret Santa.  Hannah explains: “You create a series of cards that are split in two, at the top of the card you write “you are number ” and on the bottom you write “you are buying for number . “You do this for each person, lay them on a table, shuffle them around and go along with a pair of scissors and cut the cards in two. “At that point, you can create your derangement just by shting the top half of the cards along by one. By doing this, you will guarantee that the top number will not match the bottom number. She concludes: “Everybody will pick up a brand new top and bottom half, then you write a list of all of the numbers in the office and everybody can fill in what number they are. “They now have no idea who anyone  is buying for.” This calculation means that everybody will have an equal chance of buying for everybody . Alternatively, you could make le a lot easier and get it sorted online with a random generator - but we’ll let you decide. news weird-news most-haunted-pub-cctv-glass-"Spooky moment a glass spontaneously shatters into piecesByHannah Molnar:,  Dec | commentsA pub dubbed by locals as the town’s “most haunted” has released footage of a glass “spontaneously shattering in spooky CCTV.Security cameras in Longs Arms, which has long held the title of Wiltshireaposs most haunted pub, captured the bizarre moment when a glass appears to burst into small pieces. Landlord, Rob Allcock, said he couldnapost stop watching it.Since posting the video on Twitter, many people have hypothesised that something must have fallen on top of the glass,Dorset Live reports.But Rob said this wasn’t possible . “Itaposs a single glass - theyaposre not touching and this is a toughened Guinness glass with the bottom blown out of it,” he said.  The glass was placed upside down, Rob explained, on a hygienic drip mat with a gap underneath to allow the glass to dry. Thereaposs no way anything could have hit it. According to Rob, the toughened glass at the bottom, which is not supposed to shatter, burst as though”someone had crushed it from the top”. Itaposs just really odd and you can see from my weaposs reaction, sheaposs pretty freaked out, he added. The Longs Arms pub is no stranger to paranormal activity although nothing of this nature had ever occurred before. Husband and we Rob and Liz have run The Longs Arms in South Wraxall for  years, becoming custodians near-on four years ago.  In that time a number of phantoms have presented themselves to regulars, visitors, customers and the owners, according to Rob. He recounts scenarios where children have been seen sitting with customers, eating dinner.When a customer goes to leave, theyaposd say to Rob: Wasnapost that little boy really well behaved  And heaposd explain there were just two adults sitting there, with no children. People have been pushed into the toilets from the back of their heads, while others have seen men in the garden, picking apples up. Things around the pub have been known to move around, but no glass has ever spontaneously burst before. Normally, you see things and then you look back and thereaposs no one there. Iaposll be walking through to the kitchen, which has a door that opens both ways, and it will open assomeone is on the other side, pulling it - you get used to things like that,” Rob said.  Most famously is the little black and white dog, that has been seen so vividly by all people and children alike that they actually attempt to pick him up, and kids chase him round the tables, even though thereaposs nothing there. Rob explained that when he reveals to people that the dog isnapost there, they get quite freaked out. Theyaposve seen it, and you canapost argue with someone once theyaposve seen it, he added. He added: Growing up in pubs in Liverpool, my mum always used to tell me, donapost be afraid of the ghostly things you see, be scared of the living. Iaposve always kept that with me - what are they going to do  Itaposs not a horror film, itaposs just what it is. I canapost explain it, I just donapost feel like theyaposre going to harm us. Although over the years, loads of people have told Rob and Liz, they ought to get a ghost hunter in, Rob says no way. We might see things, hear things, feel things, but itaposs all good - I donapost want to start upsetting anything - Iaposd rather just let things be. It is hypothesised that The Longs Arms dates back to the th century, however, it is not exactly known - although it is clear that the building has been an inn since . The Allcocks are the only other family after the Longs that have owned the pub in  years. title: mum upset over teachers unsupportive
story: Mum upset over teachers unsupportive text - but some say shes being unreasonableA mum has asked for some advice after receiving and unsupportive text message from her sons piano teacher, but other parents arent convinced she should be upset over itThe mum was upset by the textImage: GettyByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Dec | commentsWhen it comes to their children, itaposs only natural that some parents can get pretty defensive, pretty quickly. You want to protect your little ones and keep them out of harmaposs way.One mum was recently left feeling rather upset for her -year-old son, after receiving a text from his piano teacher.The unnamed woman thought the message was rather unsupportive and took to Mumsnetaposs Am I Being Unreasonable forum to ask fellow parents for their advice.She wrote: Am I being unreasonable to be upset by piano teacheraposs comments  My -year-old son ‘Josh’ has been having piano lessons for six weeks and I have received this text from his teacher.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.Josh seems to be struggling in his lessons. He complains his fingers are tired even after we have just started the lesson. This morning he told me he has been doing too much writing in class beforehand. He seems to talk a lot and doesn’t seem particularly interested.He tells me he practises on his iPad   I’m not sure the piano is right for Josh, maybe consider a dferent instrument next term.The parent added: AIBU to feel upset and my son is being unsupported The post caused a stir among fellow Mumsnet users as many agreed she was being unreasonable.  Hundreds responded to the mum, with one person replying: He definitely doesnapost sound interested though. I donapost know what you expect her to do Another said: I think sheaposs trying to be kind and I say that as a mum who has spent thousands on piano lessons for my kids over the last few years. One of them I wish their piano teacher had said this, itaposs so expensive andthey donapost want to practise itaposs such a waste of money! A third commented: I would expect a  year old to try a bit harder tbh. What do you expect her to do  It doesnapost sound like his behaviour is great in lessonshe is complaining making excuses all the time. Someone  thought: Lessons are a waste of timehe doesnapostpractice. I am taking music lessons as an adult and my teacher is quite open that without time, commitment and passion itaposs a waste of everyoneaposs time. The mum later added in the comments that it was her son who wanted to go to lessons and she hadnapost forced him, saying: He wanted to learn and we are in the process of buying a second-hand keyboard so he can practise, I just think the comments are a little harsh and abrupt - I think a phone call would have been kinder.What do you think  Let us know in the comments below.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON ViralParentingTeachers" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: nurse shares most jaw dropping
story: Nurse shares most jaw-dropping deathbed confessions shes heard - including murderA nurse who works in the Intensive Care Unit has been sharing some of the most shocking deathbed confessions shes heard while working in hospitals over the last three yearsNurse JJ says sharing the deathbed confessions has helped her deal with them Image: Nurse JJ TikTokByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Dec | commentsWe all have our own secrets in le, but there are certainly some whose secrets are much darker than others. Andthereaposs one person who can attest to this, itaposs a TikTok user known as Nurse JJ.Posting under the username @graysymmetrical, the nurse shares behind the scenes tidbits from her job in the Intensive Care Unit of a hospital in the US. Most notably sheaposs gone viral for revealing some of the most jaw-dropping deathbed confessions she claims to have ever heard while working, which include murder, kidnapping and leading a double le.Unsurprisingly some of the confessions are downright terrying and Nurse JJ has said she wishes some people had taken their secrets to the grave instead of telling her as she now has to live with it. Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.In one clip, the nurse shares how one patient confessed he had unalived his neighbour because of where he wanted to put his fence. Nurse JJ commented: He creeps into my intrusive thoughts a lot. While she claims someone  told her that they believed their uncle had been involved in a missing personaposs case.She quotes the patient in the TikTok video as saying: This girl went missing  years ago and I think my uncle took her. The sweater in her missing poster was in his garbage.And she explains how another person on their deathbed was a prisoner, who said they had taken the fall for their we after she unalived the woman he had cheated on her with, as he felt guilty.  Some of the other confessions were still bizarre but thankfully werenapost quite so scary. Quoting a patient in a dferent video, Nurse JJ said: I was a hairdresser for twenty years and I kept all of the aposdonatedapos hair to knit blankets with. Similarly, another user reportedly told her how they had been stealing money from their blind friend. A sixth admitted to having two families and shared that they were worried about who would turn up to the funeral. After sharing the first  confessions, Nurse JJ answered some questions on TikTok about them and where they came from as several of her followers had begun to question whether or not they were real. She said: This is a really common question, so thank you for asking it. I appreciate that. All  of the confessions that I posted are things that patients have told me, I canapost speak to their origin, whether they came from a place of hospital delirium, or truth, or anger. Iaposm not sure, but I do know that all  of those affected me in a very negative way and sharing them with you guys actually helps me a lot. So thank you for listening, I have a lot more stories. People in the comments were ided over the confessions, with some fascinated by them but others upset for the nurse as it was unfair to put that on her. One person replied: It is truly unfair that they tell you these things because you have to live with the fact that your patients have done so many messed up things. I feel like I wouldnapost be able to handle this, wrote a second. While a dferent user suggested: You should write a book of them.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: woman couldnt help laugh onesie
story: Woman couldn’t help but laugh as onesie makes her look like cartoon villainLibby Whitsey got the onesie for free from PrettyLittleThing during a promotion but she was still disappointed, as the onesie resembled a babygrow and left her looking like a villain from Despicable MeLibby got the onesie for free, but was still disappointed Image: TikTok libbywhitseyByJohn BettAudience WriterTfany LoVideo News Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA woman said she aposcouldnapost help but laughapos after receiving a onesie from PrettyLittleThing that left her looking like a villain from Despicable Me. TikTok star Libby Whitsey, @libbywhitsey, got the orange jumpsuit for free from the online retaileraposs Black Friday sale, where some items were completely free, as the Daily Star reports.Libby said that some people got great clothes for nothing so she was excited when her package arrived, but she was shocked when she opened it and saw a tiny orange onesie the apossize of a babygrowapos. She then tried it on and said she looked like Vector from Despicable Me, so decided to promptly donate the free item of clothing to charity.  What do you think about the bargain onesie  Let us know in the comments...Libby, from Leicester, wrote on TikTok: When everyone get nice things in the PLT  per cent off sale and I got this. She continued: I got it in a size XS and my first reaction of the piece was how small it looked before I tried it on. It looked like the size of a babygrow. In a second video, Libby puts on the onesie and she quickly sees herself as Vector the Villain in the popular animated film Despicable Me. She continued: When trying it on, I just couldn’t help but laugh at myself because it looked so funny. But to my surprise, it did stretch a lot and I managed to fit in it fine! My first reaction was how it looked exactly like Vector from Despicable Me. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. Right after posting the first video, I received hundreds of comments being compared to Vector – I even received a comment from the veried Minions TikTok account saying itaposs aposan excellent purchaseapos. Thankfully, Libby saw the funny side of the comment and said it could be fitting for Halloween next year. She added: If I did style it better, maybe wear a pair of jeans underneath to turn it into just a top, it could actually look really nice, she also suggested. Many people gave me fashion inspirations in which I could turn this fail into a really nice look. Libby managed to get another top for free during the Black Friday sale so she decided to let go of the onesie. She said: I will be donating it along with my other unwanted clothes to either a clothing bank or a charity shop so that it doesn’t go to waste.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: womans faith humanity restored after
story: Womans faith in humanity restored after stranger left note on her windscreenA woman said she was shopping when she lost her phone, then when she ed to her can she found a note on the windscreen that directed her to a safe place where it was stashedMaria ed to her car to find the kind note on her windscreen Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByJohn BettAudience WriterDanny Rigg:,  Dec | comments A woman had her faith in humanity restored after she lost her phone while she was at a Christmas market - as someone had found it and stashed it in a safe place. Mari Thomas was gutted when she lost her phone, as while it wasnapost too expensive it had huge sentimental value to her, as the Liverpool Echo reports.She tried to retrace her steps but it was no use so ed to her car, dejected, but was in for a shock as she found a note on her windscreen. It turned out someone had found the phone and left it for her at a nearby restaurant, before explaining its location in a note left on her windscreen. What do you think about the kind act  Let us know in the comments...Mari said: When I thought Iaposd lost it, you panic, donapost you  You just think, aposWhat are you going to do without it apos Itaposs not a very high-tech phone, but itaposs a decent one. To me, itaposs worth everything, because I rely on it so much. Mari had spent the day in Manchester with her husband, son and her sonaposs fiancé, buying Christmas gts - but the day was almost ruined when Mari realised sheaposd lost her phone, along with the hundreds of pictures stored on it. She continued: Those pictures are not just valuable to me but to their families as well, because we put them up on the Facebook page.As Mari approached her car, she spotted a note on the windscreen - and at first she thought her day was about to go from bad to worse. She added: I thought Iaposd parked in the wrong place and was having a telling off, to be honest. I thought, aposOh what have I done now apos For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. But when I looked at it, it was such a pleasant surprise. Mari couldnapost believe it when she read the note written on Salvation Army paper. A kind stranger took it upon themselves to leave a trail guiding Mari to her lost phone, safely stored in the Hungry Horse restaurant. She continued: I honestly couldnapost believe it that somebody had gone to the bother of writing the note in the first place, and then taking it to somewhere where I could pick it up just by going in and collecting it. I was so grateful, because like everybody , on your phone, youaposve got so many photos and memories that youaposd never get backyou lose your phone. I just want them to know that I appreciate so much what they did for me. Not many people would do that. It was very honest and honourable of them to do such a kind act.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. news world-news face-mask-glows-dark-detects-"Scientists create face mask that glows when it detects Covid-ByTom Ambrose:,  Dec | commentsScientists have developed a groundbreaking new face mask that can detect the presence of Covid thanks to a mouth filter made using ostrich cells.The cells contain antibodies that bind to the virus and it is claimed the mask can identy coronavirus in exhaled breath by shining a fluorescent light on the mask, revealing patches of virus.The mask has been developed by a research group, led by President Yasuhiro Tsukamoto of Kyoto Prefectural University in Japan, which says the LED light of a smartphone can also be used as a light source. It uses antibodies extracted from ostrich eggs from birds that have been injected with an inactive, non-threatening form of Covid.  Ostriches are capable of producing dferent antibodies neutralising foreign entities in the body. By spraying the antibodies on a filter from a mask, the reaction can detect whether the virus is present. President Tsukamoto and the group explained that they experimented over ten days with  Covid patients. They found that the masks they wore glowed under UV light.  The researchers said: The ostrich antibody for corona placed on the mouth filter of the mask captures the coronavirus in coughing, sneezing, and water. aposaposNext, a fluorescent dye-labelled ostrich antibody is reacted and the virus is visualised by irradiating with light. We also succeeded in visualising the virus antigen on the ostrich antibody-carrying filter when using the LED ultraviolet black light and the LED light of the smartphone as the light source.  This makes it easy to use on the mask even at home. Visualisation of the illness is possible. The presence of the virus can also be confirmed from the ostrich antibody-carrying mask used by a person infected with the new coronavirus for eight hours. There are plans to sell inspection kits to the general public in Japan and further afield, potentially even this year, once a patent has been secured for the technology. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from The Courier and the Evening .Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access The Courier and the EveningePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to The Courier or the EveningePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on    Monday – Friday, am – pm, or email.Your subscription to The Courier will allow you to access all of the Eveningstories which are now available on The Courier website. All of the best Eveningcontent, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on The Courier website and will be available for you as part of your subscription. If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Courier ePaper.The new website is now live. Eveningcontent can now be found on The Courier website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing EveningWeb subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Courier website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Courier website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The Courier website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you navigate to the Eveningwebsite or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Courier website.Yes. We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Eveningcolumnists. These can all be found on The Courier website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from the courts. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Eveningwebsite. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Eveningwebsite.Some Eveningcontent will be moved to The Courier website. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The Courier website.Your registration details that you set up on the Eveningwebsite will work on The Courier website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. You now have access to  free articles on the new site. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Eveningbranded newsletters. You will now receive Courier newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Courier has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Courier and the Evening . You can purchase a Courier Web or Courier ePaper subscription here: www.thecourier subscribeThe EveningePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. The Courier Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The Courier and the Evening . You can purchase a Courier Web or Courier ePaper subscription here .If you have an existing EveningWeb subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Courier site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Tele content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an EveningePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. You can purchase both The Courier and the EveningePaper subscription’s here.
